is naturally occurring in foods at low levels in both aqueous and ammonium hydroxide forms. It is commonly found in manure and decaying organic matter. However, all commercial sources are synthetically manufactured from atmospheric nitrogen, usually using natural gas as a fuel source. Ammonia is formed naturally by the decomposition of urine, manure, and dead organisms. produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"81697";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:10:"L-Arginine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:2:"AA";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:194936;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:19:"Arsenic sulfide_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"194936";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"99896;92628";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:4:"NHPD";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1792:"Realgar, or red arsenic sulfide (As4S4), is one of a variety of arsenic sulfide minerals [Merck Index]. It occurs in granular, compact, or powdery form, often in association with the related mineral, arsenic trisulfide (As2S3), also called orpiment or yellow arsenic sulfide. Realgar was, along with orpiment, was used as a pigment and both have long history of therapeutic use in traditional medicines. Realgar is widely used in the combination with traditional medicines for both external and internal uses; for example, a common TCM over-the-counter preparation, Niuhuang Jiedu Pain, contains 6.4% realgar, and the bioavailability of arsenic released from this preparation is very low[Chinese Pharmacopeia Committee 2005; Liu et al 2008]. Currently, Arsenic sulfide (As4S4) has been used in treatment of newly diagnosed and relapsed patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia rates, resulting in complete remission rates of 84.9% after administration of tetraarsenic tetrasulfide. The dose was administered by intravenous infusion for 2-3 h at a dose of 10 mg/day diluted in 5% glucose saline solution [Zhen-Yi W. 2001]. Arsenic sulfide (As4S4) will be considered as NHP, under schedule 1, item 7, Priority 5 (mineral). References:
Merck 2011: The Merck Index Version 14.1. [Online]. Whitehouse Station (NJ): Merck & Co., Inc. [Accessed 2011 January 18]. Available from: http://www.medicinescomplete.com/mc/merck/current/monographs.htm
Zhen-Yi W. 2001. Arsenic compounds as anticancer agents. Cancer Chemothr Pharmacol. 2001: 48(1). S72-S76. Available at: http://www.springerlink.com/content/46dymxmbp13qmjfb/fulltext.pdf
Liu J, Lu Y, Wu Q, Goyer RA, Waalkes MP. 2008. Mineral arsenicals in traditional medicines: Orpiment, realgar, and arsenolite. are released in the environment naturally through the weathering of minerals, in emissions from volcanoes and in marine aerosols, where the main natural source of inorganic fluorides in soil is the parent rocks, such as cryolite, fluorapatite and calcium fluoride.  Since fluoride ion is naturally occuring, compounds releasing fluoride ions will be considered as NHP's, which is why fluorides are already classified as Priority 1 NHPs listed on the Listing Of Drugs Currently Regulated As New Drugs (April 1999 Edition).  Fluorosilicic acid is an aquous solution that is most commonly manufactured as a co-product from the manufacture of phosphate fertilizers, therefore it is not found in nature.  It is used widely in fluoridation of drinking water, in which it hydrolyzes to release fluoride ions.  Since fluoride ions are listed as Priority 1 NHPs listed on the “Listing Of Drugs Currently Regulated As New Drugs (April 1999 Edition)”, Fluorosilicic acid will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 7 (Priority 1; New drug) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"81755";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Fluosilicic acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:194961;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:20:"gamma-Tocopherol_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"194961";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:4:"NHPD";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:190:"It is one of the naturally occurring forms of vitamin E and most abundant tocopherol in soybean and corn oils. Retinol/retinyl acetate/retinyl palmitate will be considered as a NHP, acceptable sources of vitamin A will be all-trans retinyl acetate (synthetically prepared from retinol), all-trans retinyl palmitate and all-trans â-carotene. In addition, Vitamin A is also listed in Schedule F as follows:     Vitamin A in oral dosage form containing more than 10,000 International Units of Vitamin A per dosage form or, where the largest recommended daily dosage shown on the label would, if consumed by a person, result in the daily intake by that person of more than 10,000 International Units of Vitamin A. Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:6:"Sodium";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:194997;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:17:"Sodium borate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"194997";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92628";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:4:"NHPD";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:933:"Borax (Na2B4O7,) is a form of hydrous sodium borate that occurs in arid regions, forming from the evaporation of saline lakes. Naturally occurring borax is translucent due to water in its structure, but develops a white powder on its surface as the water evaporates. The name borax comes from the Arabic ‘buraq’ meaning ‘white’. Borax (Sodium borate decahydrate; Na2B4O7•10H2O) is the refined form of natural sodium borate. It composed of boric oxide (B2O3), sodium oxide, and water, it is a mild, alkaline salt, white and crystalline, with excellent buffering and fluxing properties. Borax decahydrate is an important multifunctional source of B2O3, particularly for processes in which the simultaneous presence of sodium is beneficial. Borax Decahydrate is used in cosmetics, toiletries and pharmaceuticals. Sodium Borate is a salt derivative of Boric acid and falls under item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate) of NHP regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"81846";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:13:"Sodium borate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:194998;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:20:"Sodium perborate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"194998";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92722";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:4:"NHPD";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:617:"Sodium perborate is a water-soluble chemical compound manufactured by reaction of sodium tetraborate, hydrogen peroxide and sodium hydroxide.  Upon contact with water, this chemical undergoes hydrolysis, producing hydrogen peroxide and borate, which is why it is used as a source af active oxygen in detergents, laundry detergents, cleaning products and laundry bleaches. It has also some antiseptic properties and can be used as a disinfectant.  Since  sodium perborate is acting as a source for two NHPs (hydrogen peroxide; plant isolate) and (perborate as a mineral), sodium perborate will be considered as an NHP.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:113:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 6 (a synthetic duplicate)  of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:122:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 6 (un duplicat synthétique) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"81847";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Sodium perborate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:2:"SD";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:194999;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:19:"Sodium silicate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"194999";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:4:"NHPD";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:811:"Sodium silicate is a compound used in cements, textile and lumber processing; which is usually prepared using molten sodium carbonate and silicon dioxide.  Available sodium silicate is ususally composed of different forms of silicate, namely sodium orthosilicate, Na4SiO4; sodium metasilicate, Na2SiO3; sodium polysilicate, (Na2SiO3)n; sodium pyrosilicate, Na6Si2O7, and others.  This mineral compound was also used as an egg preservation agent in the early 20th Century with large success, which is why it is listed in the NHPD acceptable NMIs list.  Since silicates are sources of silicon and that silicon is currently used for different medical conditions, even if it is a synthetic compound, Sodium silicate will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 7 (Priority 5; Mineral) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"81848";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"Sodium silicate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195000;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:18:"Sodium sulfate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195000";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:4:"NHPD";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:525:"Sodium sulfate is a natural mineral and important sodium compound used in detergents, paper pulping and for many other uses.  The anhydrous form occurs in nature as the mineral Thenardite, but the major production of Sodium sulfate comes from its decahydrate form, the naturally occurring mineral Mirabilite, also known as Glauber's salt.  It is also listed in the NHPD acceptable NMI list.  For these reasons, Sodium sulfate will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 7 (Priority 5; Mineral) of the NHP is an alkaline earth metal, soft silver-white or yellowish metallic element that is highly reactive chemically. This metal turns yellow when exposed to air and occurs in celestite and strontianite. Due to its extreme reactivity to air, this element always naturally occurs combined with other elements and compounds, as in the minerals strontianite, celestite, etc. It is isolated as a yellowish metal and is somewhat malleable. Strontium commonly occurs in nature, averaging 0.034% of all igneous rock and is found chiefly as the form of the sulfate mineral celestite (SrSO4) and the carbonate strontianite (SrCO3). Strontium chloride is one of the acceptable derivative of Strontium and therefore it will be considered as an NHP under mineral, item 7, Schedule 1 of the NHP is a name given to a group of minerals, which is one of the most complicated groups of silicate minerals, since it consist of complex silicate of aluminum and boron with varying composition of sodium, calcium, iron, magnesium, lithium and other elements. The most common tourmaline is Schorl which consist of about 95% of all tourmalines in nature (see Table 1 for the tourmaline members accepted by the International Mineralogical Association).  Since tourmalines are naturally occurring minerals, they will be considered as NHPs, under Schedule 1, item 7 (Priority 5; Mineral) of the NHP Regulations.  The 14 recognized minerals in the group are:    Elbaite  Schorl  Dravite  Chromdravite  Olenite  Buergerite  Povondraite  Vanadiumdravite  Liddicoatite  Uvite  Hydroxy-feruvite  Rossmanite  Foitite (also known as Adrenaline) is both a hormone and a neurotransmitter.  This chemical is part of a family of compounds known as catecholamine, where Epinephrine have alpha- and beta-agonist activity and is the principal sympathomimetic hormone produced by the adrenal medulla.  The natural source of Epinephrine is L-Epinephrine, or its salt L-Epinephrine hydrochloride, while its synthetic duplicate is DL-Epinephrine, also produced as DL-Epinephrine hydrochloride. L-Epinephrine and L-Epinephrine hydrochloride will be considered as NHPs, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolates) of the NHP Regulations, and DL-Epinephrine and DL-Epinephrine hydrochloride The trans-form has been found in Myrocarpus silvestris, seeds of Protium brasiliensis, Chinese anise and sweet fennel oil; while the cis-form has been isolated from the leaves of Cupressus torulosa and fruits of Schinus molle.  However, both isomers are usually synthetically prepared from closely related compounds, such as from oil of turpentine or d-Limonene for the cis-form and from 1,8-Cineole or alpha-Terpineol for the trans-form.  cis-Terpin hydrate (also known as Terpinol) has been used medicinally mostly as an expectorant; therefore, to increase the expulsion of tracheal or bronchial mucus through coughing.  For these reasons, Terpin (or Terpinol) will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP CLA is not a single substance. In contrast to linoleic acid, all the CLA isomers have conjugated bonds. CLA is found naturally in animal tissues and food sources, including ruminant meats, poultry, eggs and dairy products, such as cheeses, milk and yogurt that have undergone heat processing treatments. Vegetable fats are generally poorer sources of CLA. However, CLA is produced from linoleic acid in safflower oil and sunflower oil by special treatment of these oils. CLA was originally found in milk fat where it exists in the form of phospholipids and triglycerides. Also, there is evidence that human milk contains CLA. Since conjugated linoleic acid is found naturally in animal and plant sources, therefore, CLA is considered to be NHP.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82006";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:24:"Conjugated linoleic acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195040;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:26:"Triacylglycerol lipase_APN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195040";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:280:"It is an enzyme (a group of enzymes) belonging to the esterases. Shilajeet is the most important drug of Ayurvedic and folk- medicine systems. It is produced when plant decomposition matter drips into the rocks, and centuries later, is extruded from the rocks by geothermal pressure.  It is composed of humus, minerals and several organic plant materials (such as fulvic acid and benzopyrones) that has been compressed by layers of rock.  Because of the diversity of substances found in mineral pitch, it has been used for many medical conditions, such as for anemia, arthritis and diabetes. It has been shown to significantly reduce serum triglycerides, total cholesterol, and LDL-cholesterol (the so-called "bad cholesterol") levels while increasing HDL ("good cholestrerol") levels in several clinical trials. A naturally occurring substance, Pantethine is produced as a byproduct when the body metabolizes pantothenic acid. The name "pantothenic," from which the word "pantethine" is drawn, literally means "something that is found everywhere." It may not be literally everywhere, but pantethine and pantothenic acid are found in most foods, including vegetables, dairy, eggs, grains, and meat. Liver, salmon and yeast have especially high concentrations of pantothenic acid, which the body uses to produce pantethine. 

Although Pantethine is derived from pantothenic acid, pantethine is not the same as pantothenic acid, and it is important to remember that the two substances are not interchangeable and therefore Panththine is not considered as an acceptable source for Pantothenic acid. Structurally, pantethine is a more stable disulfide form of pantothenic acid. It is also a more active metabolic substrate that is converted into an enzyme called "Co-Enzyme A," or simply, "CoA." CoA plays a critical role in the metabolism and breakdown of the three essential micronutrients namely proteins, carbohydrates and fats. Pantethine is considered as an NHP that falls under isolate, priority 2.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82021";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:10:"Pantethine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195055;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:21:"Mixed carotenoids_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195055";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"96758";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:549:"Carotenoids are organic pigments that are naturally occurring in plants and some other photosynthetic organisms like algae, some types of fungus and some bacteria. acid is a four-carbon dicarboxilic acid produced naturally as an intermediate in the citric acid cycle, an important cell's metabolic pathway.  In vivo, Oxaloacetic acid is usually in its ionized form, oxaloacetate.  This molecule is also produced in the mesophyll of plants, by the condensation of carbon dioxide with phosphoenolpyruvate, a reaction catalyzed by the enzyme oxaloacetate decarboxylase.  It is important to notice that this diacid is unstable in solution, since it decomposes to pyruvic acid by a decarboxylation reaction over hours at room temperature and days if refrigerated. These stanols are structurally related to plant sterols, being their saturated forms.  Plant stanols, or plant sterols, are also structurally related to cholesterol; however, these are not produced by animals, but by plants.  Unlike their unsaturated forms which are abundantly present in plant cells, stanols are known to occur in nature as trace amounts; although in quantifiable amounts in cereals, fruits and vegetables.  They are generally obtained in larger quantities by hydrogenation (saturation) of their respective sterols.  Campestanol, just like any plant sterols and stanols, are known to lower cholesterol serum level by reducing the absorption of both dietary and biliary cholesterol. Campestanol will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82037";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Campestanol";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195071;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:19:"beta-Sitostanol_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195071";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:922:"beta-Sitostanol is a member of the known family of naturally occurring compounds named plant stanols.  These stanols are structurally related to plant sterols, being their saturated forms.  Plant stanols, or plant sterols, are also structurally related to cholesterol; however, these are not produced by animals, but by plants.  Unlike their unsaturated forms which are abundantly present in plant cells, stanols are known to occur in nature as trace amounts; although in quantifiable amounts in cereals, fruits and vegetables.  They are generally obtained in larger quantities by hydrogenation (saturation) of their respective sterols.  beta-Sitostanol, just like any plant sterols and stanols, are known to lower cholesterol serum level by reducing the absorption of both dietary and biliary cholesterol. beta-Sitostanol will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82038";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"beta-Sitostanol";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195072;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:13:"Hordenine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195072";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:473:"Hordenine is a potent phenylethylamine alkaloid used as an antibacterial, antibiotic, diuretic and disinfectant.  It is also known as a sympathomimetic, activating both the nicotinic and adrenergic receptors.  This naturally occurring alkaloid has been isolated from many plant species, including barley, few algae and fungi; but mostly from the Cactaceae family. Hordenine will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82039";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:9:"Hordenine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195073;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:21:"Aristolochic acid_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195073";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93188;93355";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:882:"Aristolochic acid is a naturally occurring compound, found mostly in Aristolochia and Asarum species, which are both in the Aristolochiaceae family of plants; as well as in some butterflies.  Its biological importance is associated with being used as a phospholipase A2 inhibitor, antineoplastic, antiseptic, antiinflammatory, bactericidal agent and platelet aggregation inhibitor.  Despite the fact that Aristolochic acid is a well known carcinogen and nephrotoxic molecule, which is why Aristolochic acid and all other herbs containing this compound is currently listed in the Restricted Substances not in the Food and Drug Regulations, it is still sometimes used as an herbal remedy for weight loss.  Despite these facts, Aristolochic acid meets the definition of a NHP; therefore will be considered as such, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:363:"This ingredient is on the Restricted Substances list in the Natural Health Products Compliance Guide. Coenzyme Q10 owes its antioxidant properties to its reduced form, Ubiquinol, where it prevents the generation of free radicals as well as oxidative modifications of proteins, lipids, and DNA.  Also, Coenzyme Q10, through its reduced form, possesses the ability to regenerate other powerfull lipophilic antioxidants, such as alpha-Tocopherol. (also known as Narcotine) is an opioid alkaloid isolated from the opium poppy plant, Papaver somniferum, and from other plants in the papaveraceae family.  This naturally occurring chemical has been used mostly as an antitussive agent, and known as a by-product present in the water-insoluble extraction fraction of morphine from opium.  Despite the fact that it is listed in the List of Prohibited and Restricted Cosmetic Ingredients as follows:
Noscapine (128-62-1) and its salts 
Noscapine is not included in the Opium Poppy listing of the Schedule I of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act; therefore, being a naturally occurring substance, it will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82055";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:9:"Noscapine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195088;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:18:"Silver nitrate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195088";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1014:"Silver nitrate is the most important silver compound because of its versatility and low cost.  Silver salts are known for their antiseptic properties, which is why Silver nitrate have been used to treat or prevent many bacterial infections, such as in topical creams to treat burns and in newborn eye drops to prevent contraction of gonorrhoea or chlamydia from the mother.  SIlver itself is generally recognized as non-toxic; however, silver salts are, which is why silver and its salts are currently listed in the Cosmetic Ingredients Hotlist as follows: 
Silver (7440-22-4) and its salts 
Restricted to concentrations equal to or less than 0.04% in mouthwash. 
Any cosmetic containing silver and/or its salts shall carry cautionary statements to the effect: "This product contains silver and/or silver salts, avoid contact with broken or abraded skin." 
Despite this fact, Silver nitrate, being a salt of the naturally occurring element Silver, will be considered as such, a source of Silver; therefore, an NHP.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82056";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:14:"Silver nitrate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195089;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Hyoscine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195089";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:789:"Scopolamine (also known as hyoscine) is a tropane alkaloid drug obtained from plants of the family Solanaceae (nightshades), such as henbane or jimson weed (Datura species). It is part of the secondary metabolites of plants. Scopolamine is named after the genus Scopolia. The name "hyoscine" is from the scientific name for henbane, Hyoscyamus niger. The drug is highly toxic and has to be used in minute doses. Scopolamine and its quaternary derivatives act as antimuscarinics like atropine, but may have more central nervous system effects. Among the many uses are as an anesthetic premedication, in urinary incontinence, in motion sickness, as an antispasmodic, and as a mydriatic and cycloplegic. Scopolamine will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under acid is a solution of hydrogen chloride gas in water.  This chemical is a strong inorganic acid that is used in many industrial processes, such as in the regeneration of ion exchange resins, in the regulation of pH and neutralization, in the prickling of steel, in the production of inorganic compounds, in the production of organic compounds and so on.  It has also been used medicinally as a pharmaceutical aid (acidifier) and as a gastric acidifier in animal medicine.  Even if Hydrochloric acid is mostly used in industrial processes, it is also known to occur in living organisms, being the major constituent of the human digestive fluid, gastric acid, which is secreted by parietal cells into the lumen of the stomach.  Therefore, Hydrochloric acid will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82061";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Hydrochloric acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195092;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:18:"Oleanolic acid_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195092";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:280:"Oleanolic acid occurs in the free state in different leaves. acid  is a stereoisomer (epimer) of Ascorbic acid, which is why it is mostly known under the name Isoascorbic acid. It has taste properties superior to stevioside (US-NLM 2009) (CRC-DNP 2009). Rebaudioside A commercial used as a highly sweet natural product; its sweetness intensity rated as about 240 times sweeter than sucrose (Kim and Kinghorn 2002). Questions on specifications, safety and special population effects have prevented steviol glycosides from obtaining a legal status permitting their use as a sweetener in most countries. However, recent studies concluded that high purity Rebaudioside A produced to food-grade specifications and according to Good Manufacturing Practices is safe for human consumption under its intended conditions of use as a general purpose sweetener (Brusick 2008; Carakostas, Curry et al. 2008). Rebaudioside A may offer therapeutic benefits, as it has anti-hyperglycemic, anti-hypertensive, anti-inflammatory, anti-tumor, anti-diarrheal, diuretic, and immunomodulatory actions (Chatsudthipong and Muanprasat 2009). It is the universal energy molecule used by the body and has been used in a variety of medical conditions.  Since it is the energy molecule used by our body, some suggests that ATP supplementation can aid and assist in improving energy levels and help support conditions such as chronic fatigue, or related disorders usually caused by aging. Mammalian skeletal muscle at rest contains 350-400 mg of ATP per 100g and it has been isolated from animals, such as rabbits.  Because it is readily hydrolysed to ADP, AMP and down to adenosine itself, ATP must be administered by injection or by sublingual absorption.  However, its stabilized disodium salt is now used in energy-boosting bodybuilding supplementations, where it is known under the trade mark name PEAK ATP.  ATP, the non-injectable dosage form, will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82094";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:22:"Adenosine triphosphate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195115;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:16:"Formaldehyde_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195115";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:741:"Formaldehyde is the simplest aldehyde which readily results from the incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials. Formaldehyde occurs naturally in the environment and is the product of many natural processes. It is released during biomass combustion, such as forest and brush fires. In water, it is also formed by the irradiation of humic substances by sunlight. As a metabolic intermediate, formaldehyde is present at low levels in most living organisms. It is emitted by bacteria, algae, plankton, and vegetation. It has been used as disinfectant (in medicine) and as precursor in chemical industry. However there is some concerns about its toxicity. It will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82095";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Formaldehyde";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195116;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:26:"Fructooligosaccharides_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195116";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:623:"Fructo-oligosaccharides (FOS) typically refer to short-chain oligosaccharides comprised of D-fructose and D-glucose, containing from 3 to 5 monosaccharide units. FOS, also called neosugar and short-chain FOS (scFOS), are produced on a commercial scale from sucrose using a fungal fructosyltransferase enzyme. FOS is extracted from fruits and vegetables like bananas, onions, chicory root, garlic, asparagus, barley, wheat, and tomatoes. acid (6-O-(dimethylaminoacetyl)-D-gluconic acid) has been detected in 1938 and described as a natural, universally occurring substance with multiple biological and medical functions. In this respect, pangamic acid has been worldwide on the market since decades as a drug stimulating cellular respiration. In addition to the natural pangamic acid, diisopropylammonium dichloroacetate (DIPA), a synthetic product not found in biological material, is on the market requesting similar biological functions. In commercially available drugs on the German market declared as pangamic acid three separate substances can be found by chemical identification of pangamic acid, namely: (1) gluconic acid, (2) glycine and (3) diisopropylamonium dichloroacetate.  In fact, these ingredients can be used as a raw material for pangamic acid but not necessarily mixing them would produce the intended product. Therefore, for our purpose, pangamic acid will represent one single ingredient having the structure indicated below.  Since pangamic acid (and its salts) is currently listed as a Natural Health Product on the Listing of Drugs Currently Regulated as New Drugs (April 1999), it will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 1; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82099";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:13:"Pangamic acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195120;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:13:"1-Kestose_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195120";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:286:"1-Kestose is part of a family of short-chain sugars called short-chain fructooligosaccharides (sc-FOS), which are usually isolated from fruits and vegetables. quinone (Methoxatin, PQQ) is an organic molecule, discovered in 1979, which was found initially in bacteria as a reductive-oxidative cofactor.  This molecule is now known to be present in various foods, such as in vegetables and meat.  In a Nature's 2003 communication, Kato et al. reported that when mice were fed a PQQ-deficient diet, they showed several abnormalities; they grew slowly, had fragile skin, and showed poor reproductive performance.  They also demonstrated that these abnormalities were due to an enzyme malfunction, because this enzyme was involved in the degradation of the amino acid lysine, and it required PQQ to function normally.  These results suggested that PQQ should be considered as a new B vitamin in mammals. Since PQQ is widely distributed in nature and that it is a potential new vitamin, it will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82109";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:24:"Pyrroloquinoline quinone";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195129;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:14:"Cyclic AMP_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195129";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92628";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:293:"Cyclic adenosine monophosphate is a molecule that is important in many biological processes; it is derived from adenosine triphosphate (ATP). tetrafluoride is a synthetically prepared compound composed of titanium and fluorine atoms, which is usually prepared by the reaction of hydrogen fluoride with titanium tetrachloride.  It is used in organic synthesis and also has proven to be effective topically (as a 1% aqueous solution) in the prevention of dental caries.  Since titanium tetrafluoride is composed of two naturally occurring elements and as a source of these elements, it will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 7 (Priority 1; Mineral) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82114";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:22:"Titanium tetrafluoride";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195134;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Creatine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195134";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:484:"Creatine is a naturally occurring amino acid (protein building block) found mainly in muscles. Fifty percent of creatine in our bodies is ingested through the foods we eat while the other 50% is made in the liver, kidney, and pancreas. Roughly one-third is in its free form as creatine, while the remainder is bound to phosphate and called creatine phosphate or phosphocreatine. Therefore, Creatine will be considered as a NHP under Isolate, item 2, Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82115";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Creatine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195135;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:14:"Putrescine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195135";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:451:"Putrescine (or 1,4-Butanediamine) was originally detected in decaying animal tissues, but is now known to be present in all cells and certain bacterial cultures (O'Neil et al. 2001). Therefore Putrescine will be considered as a NHP, under isolate, item 2, Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82116";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:10:"Putrescine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195136;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:15:"Pyrethrin I_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195136";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92628";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:828:"Pyrethrins are a pair of natural organic compounds (Pyrethrin I and Pyrethrin II) that have potent insecticidal activity, which are isolated from the pyrethrum flowers (Chrysanthemum cinerariaefolium) that can be commercially grown to supply the insecticide. Other compounds, called pyrethroids, are synthetically prepared on the basis of the chemical structure of pyrethrins.  These compounds are also used to treat body, head and pubic lice infections. Since Pyrethrin I and Pyrethrin II can be isolated from a natural source, they will be considered as NHPs, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolates) of the NHP Regulations. Pyrethrins are associated with various side-effects, and may cause severe allergic attacks in sensitive people. This is also a safety issue that should be considered on assessing these products.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82117";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Pyrethrin I";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195137;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:16:"Pyrethrin II_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195137";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92628";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:828:"Pyrethrins are a pair of natural organic compounds (Pyrethrin I and Pyrethrin II) that have potent insecticidal activity, which are isolated from the pyrethrum flowers (Chrysanthemum cinerariaefolium) that can be commercially grown to supply the insecticide. Chemically, mesoglycan is related to the blood-thinning drug heparin and the supplement chondroitin. It has physical and organoleptic properties very similar to Sucrose, except that Isomaltulose is known to be around 42% sweetner than its functional isomer Sucrose.  Isomaltulose is also known to be produced from Sucrose by various stains of bacteria, such as Protaminobacter rubrum, Erwinia rhapontici, Serratia plymuthica, Klebsiella planticola and Pseudomona mesoacidophila.  For these reasons, Isomaltulose will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP An aglycone is the non-sugar part of a glycoside, which consist of  any molecule attached to one or more sugar groups by its anomeric carbon.  Hesperetin is usually prepared by the hydrolysis of Hesperidin, or by synthesis.  Since several studies have shown that orally administered Hesperidin is hydrolyzed by beta-glucosidases to its aglycone Hesperetin before absorption, meaning that the active ingredient in Hesperidin is in fact Hesperetin and that Hesperidin is already classified as a NHP, Hesperetin will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2: Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82132";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:10:"Hesperetin";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195152;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:15:"L-Norvaline_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195152";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"92628;93278";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:412:"Norvaline is an analog of the branched chain amino acid Valine. Several variants of microcystins exists, such as Microcystin YR produced by Microcystis aeruginosa and Microcystis viridis Tac44 and Microcystin YA produced by Anacystis cyanea.  These chemicals are also known as cyanobacterial toxins; therefore very toxic (LD50 as low as 0.056 mg/kg in mice), which is why cyanobacterial toxins screening test methods and tolerance limits are required for products containing blue-green algae. Diehl while researching a cure for arthritis. The first amount of Cetyl myristoleate was extracted from mice, but it is now known to be found in sperm whale oil and in a small gland in beaver. This chemical is part of a family of compounds known as catecholamine, where Epinephrine have alpha- and beta-agonist activity and is the principal sympathomimetic hormone produced by the adrenal medulla.  The natural source of Epinephrine is L-Epinephrine, or its salt L-Epinephrine hydrochloride, while its synthetic duplicate is DL-Epinephrine, also produced as DL-Epinephrine hydrochloride. Lanthanum has no known biological role; however, some lanthanum salts (such as Lanthanum chloride and Lanthanum carbonate) have been sold as medication to absorb excess phosphate in end-stage reanl failure and known to have some anticoagulant properties. is a digestive enzyme that cleaves peptides at the carbonyl side of tyrosine, tryptophan, phenylalanine and other amide bonds; therefore classified as a proteolytic enzyme.  This enzyme is produced in the pancreas as its inactivated form, chymotrypsinogen, followed by transportation to the duodenum where it is activated by trypsin.  It exist in different forms, such as alpha-chymotrypsin, beta-chymotrypsin, gamma-chymotrypsin, etc.   In vivo, chymotrypsin is acting in the digestive systems of mammals and other organisms, where it performs its main function by hydrolysis of peptide bonds during the intestinal digestion of proteins.  Both orally and topically, chymotrypsin has been used in the prevention or treatment of several medical conditions, mainly associated with reducing inflammation.  Therefore, chymotrypsin will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP proteins is a synonym for Whey proteins, where the word lactoserum is usually used in French for Whey.  Whey proteins is already classifed in the database as a NHP, so Lactoserum proteins should be included as another common name in this entry.

Whey proteins is considered as a NHP that falls under isolate, item 2 of schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations. Any product that have whey proteins as a medicinal ingredient in an acceptable dosage form and have a health claim will be considered as a NHP.  In addition, the source material for whey proteins should be declared by the applicant and will be assessed according our NHP Regulations.

Please note that "whey proteins supplement" is not a health claim. If it is just a dietary protein supplement with no health claims or other representation as a health product (dosage form, packaging/labelling etc.) it should be classified as a food, not a NHP";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82173";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Whey protein isolate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"APN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195187;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:28:"Whey protein concentrate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195187";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95988";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:911:"Lactoserum proteins is a synonym for Whey proteins, where the word lactoserum is usually used in French for Whey.  Whey proteins is already classifed in the database as a NHP, so Lactoserum proteins should be included as another common name in this entry.

Whey proteins is considered as a NHP that falls under isolate, item 2 of schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations. Any product that have whey proteins as a medicinal ingredient in an acceptable dosage form and have a health claim will be considered as a NHP.  In addition, the source material for whey proteins should be declared by the applicant and will be assessed according our NHP Regulations.

Please note that "whey proteins supplement" is not a health claim. When consumed in unprotected tablets or capsules, the enzyme is destroyed by acid in the stomach. However, enterically-coated tablets enable the enzyme to pass through the stomach unchanged, and be absorbed in the intestine. Serrapeptase is found in negligible amounts in the urine, suggesting that it is transported directly from the intestine into the bloodstream. It will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82188";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:21:"3,3'-Diindolylmethane";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195201;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Chitosan_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195201";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1517:"Chitosan is a linear polysaccharide, structurally similar to cellulose, composed of copolymers of glucosamine and N-acetylglucosamine, which is why chitosan is known to be an intermediate in the manufacture of glucosamine products.  This randomly distributed beta-(1-4)-linked polymer is produced commercially by deacetylation of chitin, which is extracted from shells of crustaceans such as shrimp, lobster, and crab.  Chitosan has been used in both commercial and medicinal areas.  Medicinally, it has been used for weight loss and obesity, in hypercholesterolemia, anemia, Crohn's disease, dental caries, enhancing physical strength, stimulating appetite, renal failure, and insomnia.  Topically, chitosan has also been used for periodontitis, as well as to promote donor site tissue regeneration in plastic surgery.  As a non-medicinal ingredient, Chitosan has been used as an excipient in tablets, as a disintegrant to improve drug dissolution, as a vehicle for parenteral drug delivery devices, as a carrier in controlled release drug systems, and to mask bitter tastes in oral solutions.  Commercially, chitosan is mostly used as a plant growth enhancer, by boosting the ability of plants to defend against fungal infections.  It is also used as part of a filtration process in water processing, causing fine sediment particles to bind together in addition to help in the removal of phosphorus, heavy metals, and oils from the water.  Therefore, Chitosan is considered as a NHP and also as NMI in NHP products.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82189";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Chitosan";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195202;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:23:"N-Acetylglucosamine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195202";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"96686";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:277:"N-Acetylglucosamine is the acetylated derivative of the amino sugar glucosamine, which is a constituent of cartilage proteoglycans. In insects and arthropods, Ecdysterone promotes the act of molting.

Ecdysterone is chemically similar to testosterone, which has lead to the belief that it might possess anabolic properties. Animal research suggests that Ecdysterone affects steroid receptors. It is unclear whether this effect is mediated by receptor or feedback loop regulation rather than bioconversion into steroids. However, there is no research in humans demonstrating androgenic or myotrophic effect.

Many of the original studies on Ecdysterone were done in the Soviet Union around 1988, and the researchers theorized that the primary action was that it supposedly helped increase protein synthesis (the use of protein in your liver) and therefore promoted positive nitrogen balance, which would then theoretically lead to greater muscle gains. 

Since Ecdysterone is found in many natural sources, it will be considered as a NHP under isolate, item 2, Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82198";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Ecdysterone";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195211;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:21:"Benzeneethanamine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195211";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:481:"Phenylethylamine is found in human brain (and normal urine). Nicotine bitartrate will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 1 (isolate). Please see below for the acceptable limits and dosage forms of Nicotine as NHP as indicated in the Schedule F:
Nicotine and its salts, for human use (acceptable as NHP);
(a) in natural substances;
(b) in the form of a chewing gum containing 4 mg or less of nicotine per dosage unit;
(c) in the form of a transdermal patch with a delivery rate of 22 mg or less of nicotine per day; or
(d) in a form to be administered orally by means of an inhalation device delivering 4 mg or less of nicotine per dosage unit
(e) in the form of a lozenge containing 4 mg or less of nicotine per dosage unit.

Humic acids will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Extract).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82213";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Humic acids";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195225;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:27:"Guanidinopropionic acid_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195225";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:613:"Guanidinopropionic acid occurs in the sea anemone Anthopleura japonica [1-2]. It alters creatine metabolism [3]. Guanidinopropionic acid is a physiological constituent of mammalian blood plasma, erythrocytes, brain, liver, kidney, aorta, and urine [4]. Guanidinopropionic acid will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).

[4] Sigma-Aldrich at www.sigmaaldrich.com/sigma/product%20information%20sheet/g6878pis.pdf";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82214";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:23:"Guanidinopropionic acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195226;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:21:"Hypochlorous acid_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195226";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1452:"Hypochlorous acid (HClO) is a weak and unstable acid. It occurs only in aqueous solutions when pure chlorine is added to water. In the presence of sunlight, hypochlorous acid decomposes into more hydrochloric acid and oxygen. It is widely used as a bleach, oxidizer, deodorant and disinfectant. Its potassium salt is well known to be the active ingredient in the bleach Javelle water or Eau de Javelle. It is also produced by neutrophyl granulocytes, also known as neutrophils, which are the most abundant type of white blood cells, which form a large part of the immune system.  These cells are active phagocytes, capable of ingesting or "destroying" unwanted microorganisms or foreign particles.  However, only one phagocytic event can be performed by these cells, resulting in the usage of all their glucose reserves in an extremely vigorous event, called "respiratory burst". This "respiratory burst" produces large quantities of reactive oxygen species, which kills the ingested organisms.  During this process, Myeloperoxidases (MPO), a peroxidase enzyme, produces Hypochlorous acid, which is one of the active oxygen species that contributes in the killing of the unwanted organisms, from hydrogen peroxide and chlorine anion.  Even if hypochlorous acid is only stable in solutions, it is naturally produced by immune system cells, therefore, it will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82215";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Hypochlorous acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195227;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:11:"Pinitol_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195227";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:220:"D-pinitol is a form of pinitol, a naturally-occurring compound found in certain plants, trees and foods, such as soy. Phytosphingosine is one of the most widely distributed natural sphingoid bases, which is abundant in fungi and plants (e.g. isolated from the basidiomycete Russula cyanoxantha and Saccharomyces cerevisiae), and also found in animals including humans. Phytosphingosine is structurally similar to sphingosine; phytosphingosine possesses a hydroxyl group at C-4 of the sphingoid long-chain base, whereas sphingosine has a trans-double bond between C-4 and C-5. branching enzyme (glycogen branching enzyme) is an enzyme taking part in the synthesis of glycogen by adding branches to the glycogen molecule. Glycogen is a branching polymer of large numbers of glucose units linked together. The structure is based on chains of glucose units with linkages between carbon atoms 1 and 4 of each pair of units (alpha 1, 4 linkages).   
Glycogen storage disease type IV is a very rare hereditary metabolic disorder as a result of the absence of the glycogen branching enzyme. Transglucosidase has been found in Aspergillus niger and Aspergillus oryzae. 1,4-alpha-glucan branching enzyme will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82223";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:33:"1,4-alpha-Glucan branching enzyme";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"APN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195234;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Guaiacol_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195234";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:661:"Guaiacol is naturally occurring substance used medicinally as an expectorant, antitubercular, antiseptic and as a local anesthetic.
