It is primarily composed of (1-4)-alpha-D-glucopyrano linkage with less than 10 percent (1-6)-alpha linkage. Icodextrin is a dextrin (polysaccharides produced by the hydrolysis of starch), having more than 85% of its molecules with molecular masses between 1640 and 45,000 daltons with a claimed-average molecular mass of approximately 20,000 daltons. Icodextrin is used clinically to reduce postoperative adhesions and used as the osmotic agent in peritoneal dialysis solution. Icodextrin will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82230";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:10:"Icodextrin";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195239;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:15:"Polyphenols_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195239";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:631:"Polyphenols exist in various vegetables and fruits as plant pigment or component of bitterness and astringency. They consist of flavonoids, tannins, phenol carboxylic acids and lignins. Apples contain many kinds of polyphenols, such as procyanidin, epicatechin, catechin, p-coumaroyl qunic acid, chlorogenic acid, rutin and phloridzin. The main components of polyphenols are oligomeric procyanidins. The most important flavonoids present in apple and apple products are flavanols or catechins, flavonols, and anthocyanidins. Polyphenols (apple polyphenols) will be considered NHP’s, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Extract)";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82231";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Polyphenols";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195240;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:25:"Unhydrolyzed Collagen_APN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195240";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95673";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:929:"Collagens are the most abundant proteins found in the animal kingdom. It is the major protein comprising the extracellular matrix (ECM). There are at least 12 types of collagen. Types I, II and III are the most abundant and form fibrils of similar structure. Type-II collagen is the basis for articular cartilage and hyaline cartilage.
It makes up 50% of all protein in cartilage and 85-90% of collagen of articular cartilage.Type II collagen adds structure and strength to connective tissues and is found primarily in cartilage, the jelly-like substance that fills the eyeball, the inner ear, and the center portion of the discs between the vertebrae in the spine. Chicken collagen II is type II collagen derived from the sternum of chickens. Type II chicken collagen shares some similar antigenic regions with type II human collagen. Collagen Type II will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 4 (extract).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82232";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:21:"Unhydrolyzed Collagen";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"APN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195241;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:33:"Unhydrolyzed collagen type II_APN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195241";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95673";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:929:"Collagens are the most abundant proteins found in the animal kingdom. It is the major protein comprising the extracellular matrix (ECM). There are at least 12 types of collagen. Types I, II and III are the most abundant and form fibrils of similar structure. Type-II collagen is the basis for articular cartilage and hyaline cartilage.
It makes up 50% of all protein in cartilage and 85-90% of collagen of articular cartilage.Type II collagen adds structure and strength to connective tissues and is found primarily in cartilage, the jelly-like substance that fills the eyeball, the inner ear, and the center portion of the discs between the vertebrae in the spine. Chicken collagen II is type II collagen derived from the sternum of chickens. Type II chicken collagen shares some similar antigenic regions with type II human collagen. acid is widely distributed in plants where it occurs in gums, mucilages, saponins and flavone glycosides and in animals as a constituent of mucopolysaccharides. It usually occurs in "paired" form, i.e. as a glycosidic combination with phenols, alcohols, etc. Such glucuronides form in the liver detoxify poisonous hydroxyl-containing substances. The glucuronides present in normal urine are those of phenol, cresol, and indoxyl. After the ingestion of poisons such as morphine, chloral hydrate, camphor, or turpentine, glucuronides formed with the poison or its hydroxylated derivatives appear in the urine. Glucuronic acid will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82237";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"D-Glucuronic acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195244;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:27:"Isoleucine methyl ester_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195244";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:441:"Isoleucine methyl ester is the sex pheromone component of the larva, Phyllophaga anxia (Chiral capillary gas chromatographic-electroantennographic detection(GC-EAD) analysis indicates that L-valine and L-isoleucine methyl esters are the major sex pheromone components released by females of the cranberry white grub, Phyllophaga anxia [1]). Isoleucine methyl ester will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82238";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:23:"Isoleucine methyl ester";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195245;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Oleamide_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195245";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92628";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1185:"Oleamide is isolated from the cerebrospinal fluid of humans, cats and rats and also from lichen Stereocaulon alpinum and from Desmos cochinchinensis. Oleamide is an endogenous amide of the fatty acid oleic acid. The mechanism of action of oleamide's sleep inducing effects is an area of current research. It is likely that oleamide interacts with multiple neurotransmitter systems. While structurally related to the endogenous cannabinoid anandamide, the ability of oleamide to bind the cannabinoid receptor CB1 is controversial. Synthetically produced oleamide has a variety of industrial uses including as a slip agent, a lubricant for plastic films (polyolefin) which can be used in food packing material. It is used as a dispersant in printing and dying. It is used in paper and textile industry for water-proof as well as corrosion inhibitor in oil wells. It is also used for the synthesis of organic chemicals and surfactants used in detergent, ore floating agent, fabric softener, anti-static agent, germicide, insecticide, emulsifier, anti-caking agent, lubricant and water treatment agent. Oleamide will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82239";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Oleamide";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195246;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:27:"(S)2-Aminobutanoic acid_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195246";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92871";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:411:"alpha-Aminobutyric acid (AABA) is an isomer of the amino acid aminobutyric acid. There is also gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and beta-aminobutyric acid.
alpha-aminobutyric acid is a key intermediate in the biosynthesis of ophthalmic acid or ophthalmate, which was first isolated from calf lens. It is widely distributed in nature. It will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82240";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:23:"(S)2-Aminobutanoic acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195247;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:11:"Thujone_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195247";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1038:"Thujone is a ketone and a monoterpene that exists in two stereoisomeric forms: (+)-3-thujone or α-thujone and (-)-3-thujone or β-thujone. Thujone is found in a number of plants, such as arborvitae (genus Thuja, hence the derivation of the name), Nootka Cypress, some junipers, mugwort, sage, tansy and wormwood, most notably grand wormwood (Artemisia absinthium), usually as a mix of isomers (alpha:beta) in a 1:2 ratio.  Thujone is most famous for being a chemical in the drink absinthe and many modern producers list their supposed thujone levels on the bottle. However, by recent tests it has become evident absinthe contains very little thujone. In Canada, liquor laws are the domain of the provincial governments. British Columbia has no limits on thujone content; Alberta, Ontario and Nova Scotia allow 10 mg/kg (10 ppm) thujone; Québec allows 15 mg per kg (15 ppm); and all other provinces do not allow the sale of absinthe containing thujone. Thujone will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82241";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:7:"Thujone";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195248;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:11:"Acetone_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195248";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1654:"Acetone is a colorless, mobile, flammable liquid. It is the simplest example of the ketones (as Dimethyl ketone or 2-Propanone).The most familiar household use of acetone is as the active ingredient in nail polish remover. Acetone is also used to make plastic, fibers, drugs, and other chemicals. Although mostly synthetically prepared, virtually every organ and tissue within the human body contains some acetone which is one of three biochemicals collectively referred to as ketone bodies. Acetone is produced within the body as a result of the breakdown and utilization of stored fats and lipids as a source of energy [1]. Acetone can be found as an ingredient in a variety of consumer products ranging from cosmetics to processed and unprocessed foods. Acetone has been rated as a GRAS (Generally Recognized as Safe) substance when present in beverages, baked goods, deserts, and preserves at concentrations ranging from 5 to 8 mg/L [2]. It can also be detected in measurable amounts in onions, grapes, cauliflower, tomatoes, milk, cheese, beans, peas, and other natural foods. Milk from dairy cattle may contain very high levels of acetone, ranging as high as 225 mg/L for the milk from hyperketo-nemic cows [3]. Acetone has also been identified, but not quantified, in air samples from numerous plants and microorganisms. In addition to its elimination in the expired air of all mammals, acetone is excreted as a metabolic end-product by some bacteria (Clostridium butylicium), molds, fungi (Paecilaomyces variotii), and algae (Cryptomonas ovata palustris) [4-6]. Acetone will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82242";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:7:"Acetone";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195249;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:18:"Barium sulfate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195249";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1162:"Barium sulfate is a white crystalline solid with the chemical formula BaSO4. It is poorly soluble in water and other traditional solvents but is soluble in concentrated sulfuric acid. The mineral barite is composed largely of barium sulfate and is a common ore of barium. Barium sulfate is frequently used clinically as a radiocontrast agent for X-ray imaging and other diagnostic procedures. It is most often used in imaging of the GI tract during what is colloquially known as a 'Barium meal'. Although barium is a heavy metal, and its water-soluble compounds are often highly toxic, the extremely low solubility of barium sulfate protects the patient from absorbing harmful amounts of the metal. Barium sulfate is also readily removed from the body. Other uses: manuf photographic papers, artificial ivory, cello -phane; filler for rubber, linoleum, oil cloth, polymeric fibers and resins, paper, lithographic inks; as a water-color pigment for colored paper, in wallpaper; as a size for modifying the colors of other pigments; in heavy concrete for radiation shield. Barium sulfate will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 7, Priority 5 (Mineral).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82243";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:14:"Barium sulfate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195250;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Capsiate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195250";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:318:"Capsiate has been extracted from a non-pungent cultivar of red pepper, CH-19 sweet, and shown to be a capsaicin analogue (capsinoids) that has an ester bond instead of the amide bond between the vanillyl moiety and fatty acid chain. The role or functions of bioflavonoids in plants varies, going from providing pigmentation in flowers to the protection against microbes and insects.   These chemicals are most famously known for their antioxidant activity, since their chemical structure usually includes a polyphenol moiety, where polyphenols are considered as very good radical scavengers. Maltodextrins are derived from starches, and because starches can assume a wide variety of chemical structures, the actual chemical nature of maltodextrins –and thus RMD – is poorly understood. High temperature and enzymatic treatment can modify some starches to make them more resistant to digestion, which is purposefully characterized by the rearrangement of a portion of normal alpha-1,4-glucose linkages of corn starch molecules to random 1,2-, 1,3- and 1,4-alpha and beta linkages. The human digestive system effectively digests only alpha -1,4- linkages; therefore, other linkages created are resistant to digestion, so they are not absorbed in the small intestine and are passed on to the large intestine.  This is the reason why this type of maltodextrins is used as dietary fibre.  Resistant Maltodextrin will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priotity 2 (Extract).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82247";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:23:"Resistant maltodextrins";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195254;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:19:"Mercuric iodide_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195254";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:471:"Mercury (II) iodide [or Mercuric iodide (HgI2)] is a red-orange crystal. In aqueous solution, this substance depolymerize to Sodium trimetaphosphate and Sodium orthophosphates [1].  SHMP is mostly used as a sequestrant and in various industrial applications, such as in water softeners and detergents, for leather tanning, dyeing, laundry work, and textile processing [1,2].  Recently, this ingredient has been added to dentifrices as a calcium-sequestring (or anticalculus) agent for its mineralization inhibitor properties [3,4].  These mineralization inhibitors, such as pyrophosphates, are believed to bind to site on tooth surface, bind to calcium in tartar and solution, preventing calculus formation (which is the result of calcium phosphate mineralization in dental plaque above the free gingival margin) [3,5].  The fact that Sodium hexametaphosphate is a polymeric form of phosphates is believed to be the reason why it shows improved efficacy, having a higher affinity to enamel [3,5].  

Since various phosphate minerals exist in nature and because the effect of Sodium hexametaphosphate appears to be due to phosphates, Sodium hexametaphosphate meets the substance component of the NHP definition, under Schedule 1, item 7 (Priority 5; Mineral) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82249";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:24:"Sodium hexametaphosphate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195256;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:16:"beta-Alanine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195256";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:556:"Beta-Alanine is the only naturally occurring beta amino acid (i.e. the amino group is at the beta-position from the carboxylate group). Polylysine will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82255";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:10:"Polylysine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195262;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:23:"Hydrolyzed collagen_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195262";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"96666";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:884:"Hydrolyzed Collagen is the hydrolysate of animal (particularly bovine, porcine, poultry) or fish collagen derived by acid, enzyme or other method of hydrolysis to make it more digestible and more easily absorbed by the body. It is composed primarily of amino acids, peptides, and proteins.  It is characterized by a significant level of hydroxyproline residues[1,2].  For industrial production purposes, gelatin is first obtained from raw material by acidic or alkaline partial hydrolysis and thereafter the ‘hydrolyzed collagens’ are produced by enzymatic hydrolysis of the gelatin under controlled conditions.  The methods applied to characterize the molecular weight of hydrolyzed collagen has been recently investigated [3].  Hydrolyzed collagen will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 4 (Extract).

Thiocyanate is produced by the reaction of elemental sulfur or thiosulfate with cyanide. Thiocyanate is naturally present in saliva [3,4].  Potassium thiocyanate is particularly important as an intermediate and a final product in the pharmaceuticals industry.  It is added to toothpastes and mouthwashes to approximately double the quantity of natural thiocyanate.  In the lactoperoxidase system, it increases the antibacterial activity in combination with peroxides [5]. It is a slow-acting anti-arthritic drug used for the treatment of osteoarthritis [3,4]. Diacerein is entirely converted into Rhein before reaching the systemic circulation, which is why Rhein is believed to be responsible for the pharmacological activity of Diacerein [5].  For these reasons, Diacerein will be considered as a source for Rhein; a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).

'Clinical Pharmacokinetics of Diacerein', Clinical Pharmacokinetics, 1998, Vol. 35 Issue 5, p347-359";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82262";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:9:"Diacerein";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195269;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Daidzein_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195269";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:144:"Daidzein is one of the active isoflavones in Red clover (plant). It will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82263";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Daidzein";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195270;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Pine tar_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195270";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2141:"Pine tar is a sticky material produced by the high temperature carbonization of pine wood in anoxic conditions (dry distillation or destructive distillation; the process of pyrolysis conducted in a distillation apparatus to allow the volatile products to be collected). The wood is decomposed by applying heat and pressure in a closed container. Pine tars are known to contain e.g. tricyclic diterpenoid resin acids, tricyclic diterpene hydrocarbons, alkylphenanthrenes and fatty acids. Identification of compounds and tar characterisation are now usually achieved by GC-MS [3-5,7]. Components of tar vary according to the pyrolytic process (e.g. method, duration, temperature) and origin of the wood (e.g. age of pine trees, type of soil and moisture conditions during tree growth). However, the four diterpenoids retene, abietic acid, dehydroabietic acid and methyl dehydroabietate are all major components in pine tar [7]. Pine tar in medicine has been used as topical antieczematic, rubefacient, and in vet. medicine as mild irritant, antiseptic in chronic skin conditions, and expectorant [1]. Although, some ingredients in original plant will be destroyed and/or methylated through the process, the remaining material contains many natural products. Therefore, ‘Pine Tar’ will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 4 (extract).

The complex is a large integral membrane protein composed of several metal prosthetic sites and 13 protein subunits in mammals.The complex contains two hemes, a cytochrome a and cytochrome a3, and two copper centers [2]. It can be isolated from various plants, e.g. pea shoots, sweet potato root; also from mammalian tissues. Cytochrome c oxidase catalyses the reaction of ferrocytochrome c with O2 to give ferricytochrome c and H2O; this is the final step in mitochondrial electron transport [3]. Cytochrom c oxidase will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).

acid, which has both aldehyde and carboxylic acid functionality [1], occurs in unripe fruit, in young green leaves, and in young sugar beets [2]. It is found in plant and animal tissues and also produced by Aspergillus niger and other microorganisms [3]. Glyoxylic acid will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).

Therefore, Homotaurine will be considered as an NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.

Neurology 1982 Mar; 32(3): 241-5.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82269";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Tramiprosate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195276;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:20:"Aluminum lactate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195276";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1183:"Aluminum Lactate is the aluminum salt of Lactic Acid. It is prepared from lactic acid and aluminum isopropoxide, aluminum chloride, or aluminum foil. It has been used in foam fire distinguishers and in dental-impression materials. It is an antiseptic [1]. It has also shown slight plaque and gingivitis reducing effect [2]. Another study shows daily home use of a dental rinse containing aluminum lactate is effective for treatment of dentinal hypersensitivity [3]. Aluminum lactae is also an acceptable non-medicinal ingredient [4]. Aluminum Lactate is a combination NHP and will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 7, Priority 5 (mineral).

[3] Higuchi Y. et al. ‘Clinical evaluation of a dental rinse containing aluminum lactate for treatment of dentinal hypersensitivity’, J. Clin. Dent. 1996, 7(1), 9-12
[4] International Cosmetic Ingredient Dictionary at www.ctfa-gov.org/pls/ctfa_gov/main.home and search for 'Aluminum lactate'";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82270";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Aluminum lactate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195277;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:19:"Glucose oxidase_APN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195277";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92628";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:915:"Glucose oxidase is an enzyme which catalyzes the oxidation of beta-D-glucose [1-3].The enzyme is produced by Penicillium notatum and other fungi (such as Aspergillus niger) and has antibacterial activity in the presence of glucose and oxygen. It is used to estimate glucose concentration in blood or urine samples through the formation of colored dyes by the hydrogen peroxide produced in the reaction [4]. Its mechanism of action was studied [5]. Glucose oxidase will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).

This compound is mostly used industrially, as a photographic fixing agent and to remove stains from negatives, in the manufacture of resins, in the production of vulcanization accelarators, in organic synthesis, etc. [2,3].  Even if Thiourea for commercial and industrial use is prepared synthetically (by fusion of ammonoium thiocyanate or by the reaction of hydrogen sulfide with calcium cyanamide in the presence of carbon dioxide [3]), it has also been detected in laburnum shrubs (Laburnum anagyroides) and it is known as a natural metabolite of the fungi Verticillium alboatrum and Bortrylius cinerea [4,5].  For this reason, Thiourea will be considered as meeting the substance aspect of the NHP definition, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations. 1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thiourea

Despite its known hallucinogenic properties and its classification as a controlled drug in other countries (such as USA), Ibogaine is not included in any of the Schedule 2 excluded substances lists; therefore, it will be considered as meeting the substance component of the NHP definition, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations. Its higher stability [2-3] and safe decomposition profile [4] makes it an acceptable source for Glutamine. N-Acetyl L-glutamine, as a source for Glutamine, will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).

Food Chem., 48(12), 6003-10";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82275";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"N-Acetyl-L-glutamine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195282;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:25:"N-Acetyl-L-methionine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195282";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:587:"N-acetyl L-methionine is the N-acetylated derivative of Methionine [1-2]. It is hydrolysed to L-methionine by acylase I, an enzyme found in several mammalian tissues, i.e. intestine, liver and kidney [3]. N-acetyl-L-methionine is known as an acceptable source for Methionine [4]. N-acetyl-L-methionine will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).

[4] www.efsa.europa.eu/EFSA/Scientific_Opinion/opinion_afc_05_en1.pdf";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82276";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:21:"N-Acetyl-L-methionine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195283;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:9:"Amber_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195283";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:613:"Shahriar Khadem and Tagenine Alladin
2008-05-10, 11:49 AM

Amber is the fossil resin from the extinct pine tree Pinites succinifera (Goepp.) Conway, Pinaceae. It is found along the Baltic coast, also mined in Samland (East Prussia). Baltic amber contains: C 79%, H 10.5%, O 10.5%, succinic acid 3-8%, alpha-amyrin 20-30% [1]. Amber's structure and chemical constitution were reported [2-3]. Amber is a product which may contain resin acids and their esters, terpenes, and oxidation or polymerization products of these terpenes [4]. Amber will be considered as a NHP, under schedule1, item 2, Priority 4 (extract).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82277";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:5:"Amber";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195284;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:20:"Deoxycholic acid_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195284";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:483:"Deoxycholic acid is a bile acid (found in bile of man, ox, sheep, dog, goat, and rabbit) formed by bacterial action from cholate. It acts as a detergent to solubilize fats for intestinal absorption. It is reabsorbed itself, and is used as a choleretic and detergent (Sodium deoxycholic acid is an anionic surfactant) [1-3]. Deoxycholic acid will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).
[1] The Merck Index
[2] Dictionary of natural Products
[3] ChemID";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82278";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Deoxycholic acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195285;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:22:"N-Glycyl-L-leucine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195285";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1347:"Glycyl-L-leucine is a dipeptide [1] (a molecule consisting of two amino acids joined by a single peptide bond- in this case Glycine and Leucine). Dipeptides including Glycyl-L-leucine are hydrolized in small intestine [2-3]. Glycyl-leucine dipeptidase (Cytosol nonspecific dipeptidase) specifically hydrolizes Glycyl-L-leucine [4]. It is expected that Glycyl-L-leucine would be a source for both Glycine and Leucine [5]. Glycyl-L-leucine will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).

Physiol., 254(5 Pt 1), E588-94";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82279";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"N-Glycyl-L-leucine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195286;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:20:"Ammonium lactate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195286";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1021:"Ammonium lactate is the ammonium salt of Lactic acid. It can be prepared by neutralizing DL-lactic acid with ammonium hydroxide [1]. It can also be produced by Lactobacillus lactis BME5-18M in pH-controlled fed-batch fermentation [2]. Ammonium lactate is an antipruritic agent (in topical form) [3-4]. Both Lactic acid and ammonium lactate showed effectiveness in treatment of foot xerosis [5]. Ammonium lactate is also an acceptable non-medicinal ingredient. Ammonium lactate (alone or as a source for Lactic acid) will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).

Assoc., 92(3), 143-8";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82280";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Ammonium lactate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195287;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:18:"Diiodotyrosine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195287";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:717:"Diiodotyrosine is found in the skeletal proteins of corals, sponges, and other marine organisms such as Heterochordaria abietina, Undaria pinnatifida, Sargassum thunbergii, Polysiphonia urceolata, Dendrodoa grossularia and Porphyra umbilicalis [1-2]. It has been isolated from Gorgonia cavollini as the DL acid [1]. Diiodotyrosine is a product from the iodination of monoiodotyrosine. In the biosynthesis of thyroid hormones, diiodotyrosine residues are coupled with other monoiodotyrosine or diiodotyrosine residues to form T4 or T3 thyroid hormones (Throxine and Triiodothyronine) [3]. It is used as 'Thyroid inhibitor' [1]. Diiodotyrosine will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82281";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:14:"Diiodotyrosine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195288;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:16:"Iron sulfide_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195288";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92628";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:880:"Iron disulfide, FeS2 [1], is found in nature as the minerals pyrite (fool’s gold) and marcasite, both of which have a brassy yellow color and a metallic luster. Pyrite is frequently found in large, well-formed crystals and is composed of iron(II) and S2(II) ions in a distorted rock salt structure. Heating solid pyrite affords Fe2O3 and SO2 in air or FeS and sulfur in a vacuum. Roasting of pyrites has been used in the past to produce SO2 for sulfuric acid production and iron(III) oxide for use as an iron ore. Marcasite is less stable than pyrite and therefore is more reactive. Iron disulfide, FeS2, can be prepared by heating Fe2O3 in H2S [2]. Iron disulfide will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 7, Priority 5 (mineral).
[1] ChemID
[2] 'Iron Compounds’ by Alan M. Stolzenberg, Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology 2001 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82282";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Iron sulfide";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195289;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Agmatine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195289";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:663:"Agmatine is a form of decarboxylated arginine, isolated from several plant and animal sources; present in ergot, pollen of Ambrosia artemisiifolia (Compositae), the sea anemone Anthopleura japonica, herring semen, and in octopus muscle. It is the metabolic intermediate for polyamines. Agmatine is synthesized in mammalian brain [1-3]. It is an endogenous neurotransmitter, a NMDA receptor antagonist and nitric oxide synthase inhibitor. Agmatine inhibits hyperalgesia and tolerance to morphine [2]. Agmatine will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).

Fifty percent of creatine in our bodies is ingested through the foods we eat while the other 50% is made in the liver, kidney, and pancreas. Roughly one-third is in its free form as creatine, while the remainder is bound to phosphate and called creatine phosphate or phosphocreatine. Therefore, Creatine will be considered as a NHP under Isolate, item 2, Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82284";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Creatine monohydrate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195291;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:29:"Aluminum ammonium sulfate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195291";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:904:"Aluminum ammonium sulfate NH4Al(SO4)2 [Ammonium Alum with 12H2O (dodecahydrate)], occurs in nature as Tschermigite [1], is a white crystalline double sulfate of aluminium used in purifying drinking water, in baking powders, dyeing and printing fabrics, manuf pigments, lakes, artificial gems, paper, vegetable glue, marble and porcelain cements; fire proofing, tanning,  electrolytic copperplating and in therapeutic application as astringent, and styptic [2]. Ammonium alum is made mainly by dissolving aluminum hydroxide in sulfuric acid and adding ammonium sulfate but sometimes by the reaction of ammonia gas with aluminum sulfate and sulfuric acid [1]. Aluminum ammonium sulfate will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 7, Priority 5 (mineral).

[2] The Merck Index";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82285";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:25:"Aluminum ammonium sulfate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195292;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:15:"Pea Protein_APN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195292";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1635:"Protein(s) from Pea (Pisum sativum) [1] can be prepared by extraction and further purification to generate 'Pea Protein Isolate'. Peas, as other legumes, contain a variety of antitutritional and antiphysiological factors which negatively influence the quality of their proteins. A process for pea protein isolate production, resulting in low content of phytate and oligosaccharides had been developed which made it a suitable protein source for infant formula production [2]. Pea protein can also be used as a non-medicinal ingredient. Films based on pea protein combine good strength with high elongation at break, allowing for instance packaging applications. Its surface activity can be tailored by variation of molecular weight, and by modifying the hydrophobicity. This opens the possibility for pea protein to be used as surfactants in coatings, paints and adhesives. Pea protein isolate shows good potential as matrix material for the microencapsulation of b-carotene, by means of supercritical CO2 technology [3]. Pea protein(s) will be considered NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 or 4-depends on the information provided (Isolate or Extract).

A Review’ 2001 Nahrung/Food, 45(6), pp. 408-411";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82286";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Pea Protein";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"APN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195293;a:26:{s:5:"title";s:15:"Brevetoxins_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195293";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1038:"Brevetoxins, i.e. Brevetoxin A, B,C, and many others, are structurally unique marine neurotoxins produced by the “red-tide” dinoflagellate Ptychodiscus brevis Davis (Karenia brevis, formerly Gymnodinium breve Davis). Dense growths of these algae have been responsible for massive fish kills, mollusk poisoning and human food poisoning in the Gulf of Mexico and along the Florida coast. Unlike previously isolated dinoflagellate toxins, such as saxitoxin which are water-soluble sodium channel blockers, the brevetoxins are lipid-soluble sodium channel activators [1-2]. Brevetoxin interact with at least three receptors located in neuronal, pulmonary, and enzymatic regulatory systems of living organisms [3]. However, since brevetoxins are natural products, they are considered as NHPs, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).

[2] ChemID

Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Glucomannan";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195301;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Spinosad_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195301";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"92628;92632";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1559:"Spinosad (Fig. 1) is an insecticide derived/isolated from the fermentation broth of Saccharopolyspora spinosa [1,2,3,4].  This product is composed of numerous spinosyns; where spinosyns A and D are knonw as the most abundant (88% in a ratio of about 7:1) and regarded as the most active component of Spinosad [5].  These macrocyclic lactones are believed to exert their insecticidal activity by causing rapid excitation of the targeted insect central nervous system, probably through the interaction and binding at the nicotinacetylcholine and gamma-amino butyric acid receptors, while having little or no effect on non-targeted insects and mammals [6,7].  This is the reason why Spinosad is the main active ingredient in many marketed insecticide and animal health formulations, while being investigated for human health applications, such as against human lice [7,8].  Interestingly, the Dictionary of Natural Products [3] suggests, since the word 'antibiotic' is present in synonyms and in the general statement, that Spinosad or its constituents might have antibiotic properties; however, such information couldn't be verified and/or was not found elsewhere.  Therefore, Spinosad, as derived/isolated from the actomycete bacterium Saccharopolyspora spinosa and provided that it is not added to Schedule F without proper qualifier(s) and/or not used as an antibiotic, meets the substance aspect of the NHP definition, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.

Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"Stannic sulfide";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195307;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:15:"Cantharidin_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195307";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:17:"92653;92722;93355";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1097:"Cantharidin occurs in Lytta vesicatoria and many other insects. Cantharides (the source of Cantharidin) have been used externally as rubefacients, counterirritants and vesicants, but their use in cosmetic products is banned in the UK. Reputed aphrodisiac, component of "Spanish fly" [1-2]. Cantharidin is a potent and specific inhibitor of protein phosphatases 1 (PP1) and 2A (PP2A). This compound can produce severe skin inflammation, and is extremely toxic if ingested orally. Its LDLo(lethal dose low) in oral form for human is 0.428mg/kg [3]. Cantharis vesicatoria and Cantharidin are listed in 'Restricted Substances not in the Food and Drug Regulations' [4], meaning the compliance approach to these substances should be taken in conjunction with the 'Risk-Based Approach'. However, Cantharis is acceptable in homeopathic medicines at potencies of 3X or higher, and Cantharidinum or Cantharidin is acceptable in homeopathic medicines at potencies of 8X or higher [4]. Cantharidin is, in fact, a natural product and will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:466:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations. This ingredient is on the Restricted Substances list in the Natural Health Products Compliance Guide. Unauthorized products with this ingredient are subject to the risk-based approach to compliance. A product licence must be obtained prior to marketing in Canada . Reference:http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/dhp-mps/prodnatur/legislation/docs/complian-conform_guide-eng.php";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels.";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82305";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Cantharidin";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195308;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:14:"Chloroform_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195308";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:17:"92628;92722;92722";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:793:"Chloroform (CHCl3, Fig. 1) is a chemical member of the family of compounds known as trihalomethanes [1,2].  It can be prepared from the addition of sulfuric acid to acetone and bleaching powder, or by the carefully controlled chlorination of methane [3].  Industrially, Chlorofrom has been mostly used as a solvent, or in the synthesis of other chlorinated compounds [1].  Medicinally, it was once used as a volatile halogenated anaesthetic, but nowadays safer drugs are preferred, because of its known toxicity [3,4].  Chloroform is also known to be found in many natural sources [5,6,7], including various algae [8,9]. For this reason, Chloroform will be considered as meeting the substance aspect of the NHP definition, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82306";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:10:"Chloroform";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195309;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:23:"Phosphatidylcholine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195309";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92679";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:245:"Phospholipids is found in every cell membrane in our bodies and its molecules is composed of a combination of an amino acid  and a fatty acid components. Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:24:"Phosphatidylethanolamine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195311;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:15:"Methenamine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195311";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92657";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:946:"Methenamine (Fig. 1) is an anti-infective agent, prepared from formaldehyde and ammonia, used in the treatment of urinary tract infections [1,2,3].  This compound, mostly administered as its mandelate or hippurate salt, owes its activity to the naturally occurring compound formaldehyde, as Methenamine is slowly hydrolyzed to formaldehyde and ammonia when reaching acidic urine. Formaldehyde is a very strong astringent but is not pleasant to use as is which may cause skin irritation and systemic reactions. Methenamine, in water or when applied to the skin, decomposes to generate formaldehyde in small quantities which do not cause side effects [5]. Methenamine is used topically in antiperspirant products as it liberates formaldehyde in the presence of acid sweat [4].  As Methenamine is acting as a prodrug for the naturally occurring compound formaldehyde, it will be considered as a source of it and therefore it is classified as an NHP.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82309";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Methenamine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195312;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:14:"Metadoxine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195312";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92550";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:402:"Metadoxine (pyridoxol L-2-pyrrolidone-5-carboxylate) is an equimolar mixture of pyrrolidone-carboxylic acid and  pyridoxine  and is used to help in recovering from alcohol addiction[1] [2]. Free D-chiro-Insositol has been detected in many plants including Cucurbita ficifolia (Cucurbitaceae) fruit extracts, lupine, pigeon pea, soybean, chickpea, mungbean and buckwheat.[2][3].  It also occurs in the form of galactosyl derivatives known as fagopyritols.  Buckwheat has been shown to contain five different fagopyritols whereas soybean, lupine, lentil, chickpea seeds contain only one. D-chiro-Inositol has also been identified as components of two different inositolphosphoglycan molecules in mammalian systems [4]. This isomer of inositol has been greatly studied in the reduction of blood glucose levels in animals [5].

Many physiological effects have been associated with this isolate, including inhibitory effect on monoamine oxidase and antidepressant-like activity (Ro et al), antihyperlipidemic activity (Borjihan et al), and stimulation of the digestive enzyme of the pancreas (Srinivasen et al).

Natural Malic acid is only present as the L-(-)-form, but has been synthesized also as the racemic form (DL-form). Malic acid is also present in the NHPD acceptable NMIs list.  It has also been used in combination with other chemicals (such as BHT, salicylic acid or arginine) for the treatment of ulcers, burns, wounds, liver disorders and dry mouth. Milk basic protein has been shown to increase the bone mineral density and improves bone metabolism in healthy young women, among other beneficial effects (Takada et al). It is a source of two NHPs (combination of NHPs), namely Creatine and Orotic acid. Three kinds of creatine orotates have been reported; creatine orotate, dicreatine orotate, and tricreatine orotate [ref.]. Having a strong clove-like odor and a spicy pungent taste, it is widely used in perfumeries and flavorings, which is why it is currently listed in the NHPD acceptable NMIs list.
