Silicic acid is a general name for a family of chemical compounds of the element silicon, hydrogen, and oxygen, with the general formula [SiOx(OH)4-2x]n. Some simple silicic acids have been identified in very dilute aqueous solution, such as metasilicic acid (H2SiO3), orthosilicic acid (H4SiO4), disilicic acid (H2Si2O5), and pyrosilicic acid (H6Si2O7); however in the solid state these probably condense to form polymeric silicic acids of complex structure (Martin 2007). Silicic acid is an acceptable source for Silicon and will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 7, Priority 5 (mineral).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82341";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Silicic acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195342;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:14:"Solanidine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195342";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92795";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:535:"Solanidine is a streoidal alkaloid found in Solanum tuberosum (potato), Cestrum purpureum, Fritillaria camtschatcensis, Rhinopetalum bucharicum and Rhinopetalum stenantherum (Merck 2006; CRC-DNP 2009). Solanidine is a toxin found in high-starch potatoes. It has a structure similar to that of diosgenine. However, the use of solanidine as a hormone precursor seems to be more difficult compared to diosgenine (De Brabander, Verheyden et al. 2007). Solanidine will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82342";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:10:"Solanidine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195343;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:13:"Sparteine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195343";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"92795;92722";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1008:"Sparteine is a quinolizidine alkaloid from several genera of the family Fabaceae, notably many Lupinus and Adenocarpus spp., Piptanthus nanus, Sarothamnus spp., Chamaecytisus spp. (CRC-DNP 2009). It is found in yellow and black lupin beans, Lupinus luteus L. and Lupinus niger Hort., Cytisus scoparius (L.) Link., Anagyris foetida L. (Merck 2006). Sparteine is known to decrease the irritability and conductivity of cardiac muscle and has been used to treat cardiac arrhythmias, restoring normal rhythm in previously arrhythmic patients. Sparteine is also stated to be a powerful oxytocic drug, which was once used to stimulate uterine contractions (Barnes, Anderson et al. 2007).It has also been of interest as an indicator of CYP2D6 genotype (US-NLM 2009). Sparteine is listed in the "List of prohibited and restricted cosmetic ingredients hot list (HC 2007) as follow: “Sparteine and its salts” (HC 2007). However, Sparteine will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82343";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:9:"Sparteine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195344;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Syringin_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195344";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92795";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:638:"Syringin isolated from Syringa vulgaris, Ligustrum spp., Jasminum spp., Eleutherococcus senticosus Phillyrea latifolia, Phillyrea decora, Paulownia tomentosa, Forsythia suspensa, Fraxinus spp. (CRC-DNP 2009). It is also isolated from lilac bark, cambial sap of spruce and from various plants (Merck 2006). Syringin used as an immunomodulatory agent, as an antiproliferative and also showed platelet aggregation inhibiting and antitumour effects (CRC-DNP 2009). Syringin appears to be related with the increase of insulin secretion (Liu, Wu et al. 2008). Syringin will be considered as a NHP, under schedule1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82344";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Syringin";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195345;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:16:"Ursolic acid_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195345";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92795";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:861:"Ursolic acid is a constituent of Rhododendron spp., Epigaea asiatica, black sea alga, family Cladophoraceae, found in wax of apples, pears and other fruits. It is widely distributed in plants (CRC-DNP 2009). Ursolic acid is also found in leaves and berries of Arctostaphylos uva-ursi (L.) Spreng (bearberry), Vaccinium macrocarpon Ait. (cranberry), Rhododendron hymenanthes Makino, and Ericaceae. It is used as an emulsifying agent in pharmaceuticals, and foods (Merck 2006). Ursolic acid acts as an antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer. The effects of ursolic acid on normal cells and tissues, however, are occasionally pro-inflammatory, although ursolic acid is able to counteract endogenous and exogenous inflammatory stimuli (Ikeda, Murakami et al. 2008). Ursolic acid will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82345";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Ursolic acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195346;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:15:"Xanthotoxol_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195346";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92795";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:623:"Xanthotoxol found in many plants including spp. of Fabaceae (Leguminosae), Apiaceae (Umbelliferae), and Rutaceae (Merck 2006; CRC-DNP 2009).It exhibits a wide range of biological properties, such as antioxidative activity, 5-HT antagonistic effect, and central nervous system activity. It has a rose-like odor, for which it is commonly used in perfumes. It is used in flavors such as peach, raspberry, grapefruit, red apple, plum, lime, orange, lemon, watermelon, pineapple and blueberry. An alternate application has been found in the use of insect repellants or deterrants. Oleic acid, linoleic acid, and linolenic acid are the main constituent fatty acids [1]. In many countries (e.g. USA, Japan, EU) diacylglycerol oil is an acceptable food additive [2]. Based on the research, intake of diacylglycerol oil is safe for human consumption when used in a manner similar to other edible oils [3]. Diacyglcerol oil as a mixture of fatty acids (ester forms) will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 4 Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"DL-Phenylalanine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:2:"AA";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195361;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:19:"p-Coumaric acid [on its (E)-form] found in many plants, e.g. peel of black cherry (Prunus serotina), lentil seeds and from red clover (Trifolium pratense) and Daviesia latifolia. It is found by Bate-Smith in 48% of investigated dicotyledonous and 55% of monocotyledonous spp. (CRC-DNP 2009) (US-NLM 2009) (Merck 2006). p-coumaric acid is the precursor of several simple phenylpropanoids, caffeic acid, ferulic acid, and sinapic acid. It plays a central role in the synthesis of lignin, lignans, flavonoids, and a wide range of other secondary phenolic constituents (Yildiz 2006). It shows cytostatic activity and acts as an immunoactivie agent, and inhibitor of stilbene oxidase (CRC-DNP 2009). A recent study demonstrated the antimelanogenic effect of p-coumaric acid in human melanocytes as well as in melanoma cells (An, Lee et al. 2008). p-Coumaric acid will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82365";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"p-Coumaric acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195362;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:31:"Ascorbic acid 2-O-glucoside_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195362";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92883";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1431:"2-O-α-D-glucopyranosyl-L-ascorbic acid [Ascorbic acid 2-glucoside or simply AA-2G (US-NLM 2009)(CRC-DNP 2009)] is a stable ascorbic acid glucoside already used as a quasi-drug principal ingredient in skin care, was approved by the Japanese government as a food additive (Tai and Gohda 2007). AA-2G is synthesized from ascorbic acid and α-glucans by regioselective transglycosylation with cyclodextrin glucanotransferase from Bacillus stearothermophillus (Kwon, Kim et al. 2007). Cyclodextrin glucanotransferases from mesophilic, thermophilic, and halophilic bacteria and maltase from the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae were also used for transglycosylation of ascorbic acid with starch, maltodextrin, γ-cyclodextrin, and maltose (Markosyan, Abelyan et al. 2007). AA-2G is stable in neutral solution and resistant to heat, light and oxidation. This vitamin C derivative is hydrolyzed to ascorbic acid by α-glucosidase and exhibits physiological activities in vitro and in vivo (Kumano, Sakamoto et al. 1998). Therefore, AA-2G is considered to be promising as a pro-vitamin C agent in the field of foods and nutrition. Recently, AA-2G has been isolated as a naturally occurring compound from Kimchi, a Korean traditional fermented vegetable food (Jun, Bae et al. 1998). Ascorbic acid 2-glucoside will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate)- is also considered as a source of vitamin C (a prodrug).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82366";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:27:"Ascorbic acid 2-O-glucoside";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195363;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:14:"Anandamide_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195363";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92847";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:412:"Anandamide (N-arachidonoylethanolamine) is an endogenous lipid that binds to cannabinoid receptors in the central nervous system and in peripheral cells. is a naturally occurring seleno-amino acid, formed by seleniferous plants, such as Astragalus busulcatus, Stanleya pinnata, and Oonopsis condensata.  Selenium dietary supplements are more and more associated with the reduction of the incidence of lung, colorectal, and prostate cancer in humans, where Methylselenocysteine is known to be one of these compounds.  It has been proposed that the fact that Methylselenocysteine is not incorporated into any proteins, unlike its cousin Selenomethionine, makes it fully available for the synthesis of other selenium-containing enzymes such as glutathione peroxidase.  For these reasons, Methylselenocysteine will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82369";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Methylselenocysteine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195366;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:33:"3-Methylcyclopentan-1,2-dione_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195366";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92847";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:373:"3-methyl-1,2-cyclopentanedione is a cyclic diketone in equilibrium with its enol form, i.e. 2-Hydroxy-5-methyl-2-cyclopenten-1-one [1]. This compound has also been isolated from Hortia arborea, Hortia badinii, Zanthoxylum rhetsa, Zanthoxylum ovalifolium and Zanthoxylum integrifoliolum . Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"alpha-Casozepine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195373;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:15:"Attapulgite_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195373";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92900";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1270:"Attapulgite or Palygorskite is a magnesium aluminium phyllosilicate with formula Mg(Al0.5-1 Fe0-0.5)Si4O10(OH). 4H2O (CAS no. 12174-11-7) [International Labour Organization] which occurs in a type of clay soil common to the Southeastern United States. It is one of the types of fuller's earth.The name attapulgite is derived from the U.S. town of Attapulgus, Georgia, in the extreme southwest corner of the state, where the mineral is abundant. It is surface-mined in the area, dry-ground and air-separated into precise particle sizes. It is characterized as having a chain structure rather than the usual sheet structure of other clays [Elmore AR, 2003].  Palygorskite is known to have been a key constituent of the pigment called "Maya Blue", which was used notably by the pre-Columbian Maya civilization of Mesoamerica on ceramics, sculptures, murals and (most probably) Maya textile. When used in medicine, it physically binds to acids and toxic substances in the stomach and digestive tract. For this reason, it has been used in several anti-diarrheal medications, including Diasorb, Donnagel, Kaopectate, and Parepectolin. As it is naturally occurring, Attapulgite will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 7 (Priority 5, mineral) of the NHP regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82378";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Attapulgite";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195374;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:34:"L-Tyrosine alpha ketoglutarate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195374";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92847";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:252:"Tyrosine alpha-ketoglutarate is the Tyrosine salt of alpha-ketoglutaric acid. In its native state, lactoferrin is only partially saturated (5-40%) and called Apolactoferrin when it is not iron-chelated. Even if lactoferrin can be produced from recombinant DNA procedures (Prohibited by Schedule D), it is usually isolated from whey, which is the watery part of milk that is separated from the curd in making cheese. Celgosivir is an oral prodrug of castanospermine and a potent inhibitor of alpha-glucosidase, an enzyme found in mammalian cells, which affects the early stages of glycoprotein processing. Celgosivir is a novel antiviral agent currently in clinical development for the treatment of chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. Non-clinical and clinical studies indicate that, following oral administration, celgosivir is readily converted to its primary metabolite castanospermine. Celgosivir will be considered as a NHP (source of Castanospermine), under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 peptides are basically L-glutamine linked with one or two other amino acids, usually L-Alanine and Glycine. Glutamine peptides are used as Glutamine supplement, since small peptides, such as Glutamine peptides, are known to be more rapidly absorbed by the organism compared to the free form of L-Glutamine. Since L-Glutamine is one of the acceptable amino acids included in the Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations, and Glutamine peptides are most likely to be cleaved to their single amino acids after being metabolized, Glutamine peptides will be considered as NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82391";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Glutamine peptides";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195386;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:13:"Genistein_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195386";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92920";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:124:"It is a phytoestrogen found in soy products. widely distributed in nature, classified as a fruit acid.  Occurs in many fruits, free and combined with potassium, calcium or magnesium.  Observed in antiquity as the acid potassium salt found deposited as a fine crystalline crust during fermentation of grape juice or tamarind juice and termed faecula (little yeast) by the Romans. D-form found only in fruits and leaves of the West African tree Bauhinia reticulata (DNP 2009). D-form although termed “unnatural”, its occurrence in nature has been demonstrated.  Obtained in small amounts from racemic tartaric acid through biochemical cleavage using Penicillium notatum, Aspergillus griseus, A. niger or other microorganisms (O’Neil et al. 2006). Supported by 68 citations found in NAPRALERTsm 2009.Tartaric acid will be considered as an NHP that falls under Isolate (Priority 2), Item 2, Schedule 1 of the NHP Identified as a component of a class of neutral lipids referred to as diol lipids, which have been identified in neutral fats found in plants, animals and microorganisms.  Unesterified 1,4-butanediol has been detected in rat brain and liver and presumably represents free diol released during the metabolic processing of diol lipids (Irwin 1996, Irwin 2006). Naturally occurring endogenous compound existing in rodent brain and liver and in human cortex and cerebellum (Barker et al. 1985). On doit noter que cet ingrédient est soumis à des exigences réglementaires additionnelles conformément aux Réglements sur les précurseurs à cause de sa présence à l'Annexe VI Partie 1 de la Loi réglementant certaines drogues et autres substances.";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82411";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:14:"1,4-Butanediol";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195406;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:18:"Red phosphorus_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195406";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92925";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:774:"Red phosphorus can be formed by heating white phosphorus to 250°C (482°F) or by exposing white phosphorus to sunlight. Phosphorus after this treatment exists as an amorphous network of atoms; further heating results in the red phosphorus becoming crystalline. Although phosphorus does not occur free in nature (O’Neil et al. 2006), it is commonly found in inorganic phosphate rocks that can act as a source for phosphorous. Elemental phosphorus is no longer used in medicine, as inorganic phosphates are given in deficiency states and bone diseases (Sweetman 2002). The white allotrope can be produced using several different methods. In one process, calcium phosphate, which is derived from phosphate rock, is heated in an electric or fuel-fired furnace in the presence of carbon and silica. Elemental phosphorus is then liberated as a vapour and can be collected under phosphoric acid. This process is similar to the first synthesis of phosphorus from calcium phosphate in urine.Although phosphorus does not occur free in nature (O’Neil et al. 2006), it is commonly found in inorganic phosphate rocks that can act as a source for phosphorous. Elemental phosphorus is no longer used in (conventional) medicine, as inorganic phosphates are given in deficiency states and bone diseases, but used in homeopathic medicine (Sweetman 2002).Note that this substance, being outlined in Schedule VI of the CDSA, could also be subject to additional regulatory requirements in accordance with the Precursor Control Regulations (Justice Canada 2002).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:327:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations. However, these claims have not yet been conclusively proven by independent research, and in fact a recent study demonstrated that the addition of the ethyl group to creatine actually reduces acid stability and accelerates its breakdown to creatinine. The researchers concluded that creatine ethyl-ester is inferior to creatine monohydrate as a source of creatine [2]. The hydrolysis can be performed by acids, enzymes, and other reagents (Winter 2009). Keratin hydrolysate will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 4 (Extract).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82428";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Hydrolyzed keratin";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195423;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:15:"Azacitidine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195423";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93052";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2399:"Azacitidine (Fig. 1), as an analog and antimetabolite of the naturally occurring pyrimidine nucleoside cytidine, has been used as an antineoplastic agent for the treatment of myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) and acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) (NIH 2009, O’Neil et al. 2009, Sweetman 2009). Indeed, through its incorporation into DNA and RNA as well as by inhibiting cytosine residues methylation (hypomethylation), Azacitidine is causing direct cytotoxic effect on abnormally proliferating hematopoietic cells characteristic of MDS and AML; and consequently, restoring normal growth control and differentiation (Siddiqui and Scott 2005, Sullivan et al. 2005).  Although not exempt from adverse events (benign to severe), clinical studies have shown Azacitidine as a relatively safe and effective substance for malignant or premalignant conditions such as the ones mentioned above, which is why the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved Azacitidine injectable suspension for the treatment of all subtypes of MDS (Kaminskas et al. 2005).  Due to its rapid catabolism by cytidine deaminase and hydrolysis in aqueous solution, Azacitidine is generally administered by subcutaneous or intravenous injection.  However, recently, a pilot pharmacokinetic study using an oral film-coated formulation demonstrated measurable Azacitidine plasma concentrations, suggesting possible bioavailability in oral dosage forms (Garcia-Manero et al. 2008).  Furthermore and worth mentioning, some references also describe Azacitidine as a nucleoside antibiotic (DNP 2009, Torikata et al. 1983, Uematsu and Suhadolnik 1972).  However, based on the information outlined above, this substance does not seem to be used as an antibiotic nowadays, but as an antineoplastic agent.  Azacitidine can be synthetically prepared or produced and isolated from fermentation of Streptoverticillium ladakanus, Actinoplanes awajinensis or Actinoplanes missouriensis (O’Neil et al. 2009, DNP 2009, Torikata et al. 1983, Uematsu and Suhadolnik 1972).  For this reason, Azacitidine meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, as defined in the NHP Regulations (Justice Canada 2009a), provided that it is not excluded by Schedule 2 of those regulations (e.g. not used as an antibiotic or administered by puncturing the dermis) or Schedule F to the Food and Drug Regulations (Justice Canada 2009b).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82429";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Azacitidine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195424;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:19:"Diamine oxidase_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195424";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93045";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:487:"Diamine oxidase, also known as Copper amine oxidase and Histaminase (Enzyme Nomenclature database) is isolated from pig kidney and was first reported by McHenry and Gavin in 1932 (Lobley 1970). It has a molecular weight of 185000 and is known to contain Cu2+ ions and pyridoxal phosphate (Lobley 1970). The enzyme catalyzes the oxidation of diamines and sometimes that of monoamines too. Diamine oxidase will be considered as an NHP, under item 3 (isolate) of Schedule 1 of the NHP regs.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82430";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"Diamine oxidase";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195425;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:19:"Zinc propionate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195425";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93061";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1922:"Zinc propionate (Fig. 1) is the 2:1 zinc salt of propionic acid, prepared by dissolving zinc oxide in dilute propionic acid and concentration of the resulting solution, mainly used as fungicide on adhesive tape to reduce plaster irritation caused by molds, fungi, and bacterial action (NIH 2009, O’Neil et al. 2009).Bioavailability studies in dogs showed that the bioavailability of zinc from zinc propionate, an organic source of zinc, was significantly higher than zinc from zinc oxide, an inorganic source of zinc, as measured by blood plasma levels (Brinkhaus et al. 1998). However, Beutler et al. (1998) showed that zinc uptake by cultured cells (monkey kidney fibroblasts and human intestinal epithelial cells) and by mouse intestine was not significantly different between zinc chloride, an inorganic source, and zinc methionine and propionate, organic sources of zinc. The authors attributed these latter observations to the ability of these sources to dissociate in aqueous solution to give equivalent amounts of ionic zinc, resulting to equivalent amounts transported into cells.Zinc propionate has also showed promises as a dietary zinc supplement to induce molt while maintaining postmolt egg quality and production (Park et al. 2004a, Park et al. 2004b), as well as limiting Salmonella enteritidis colonization (Moore et al. 2004) in laying hens, properties that have been attributed to both zinc and propionic acid counterparts of Zinc propionate.Although on animals and not convincing, the above information suggests a potential for Zinc propionate to be used as a source of both dietary zinc and propionic acid in humans. Therefore and because both zinc and propionic acid are naturally occurring substances (O’Neil et al. 2009, DNP 2009), Zinc propionate is considered as meeting the substance aspect of the NHP definition, as outlined in the Natural Health Products Regulations (Justice Canada 2009).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82431";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"Zinc propionate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195426;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:18:"Propionic acid_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195426";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93061";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:197:"It occurs in dairy products in small amounts. It is not found in free state, but in form of xylan, a polysaccharide built from D-Xylose units and occurring in association with cellulose. Xylose occurs also as part of glycosides. Peanut shells, corn cobs, and cottonseed hulls are practical sources of Xylose as well (CRC-DNP 2009; Merck 2009). Xylose has been used for the investigation of absorption from the gastrointestinal tract (Sweetman 2009). Xylose is also being used as non-medicinal ingredient mostly as flavoring agent, fragrance ingredient, humectant, or skin-Conditioning agent (Gottschalck and Bailey 2008). Xylose will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82436";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:6:"Xylose";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195431;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:17:"Hemicellulase_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195431";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93099";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:328:"Hemicellulase is an enzyme that breaks down hemicellulose. It is derived from a number of seaweeds of the class Rhodophyceae. It has no nutritive value and is used in food preparation for its gelling, thickening, and emulsifying properties. Three main types of carrageenan are used commercially, which are known in the food industry as iota-, kappa-, and lambda-carrageenan. These names do not reflect definitive chemical structures but only general differences in the composition and degree of sulfation at specific locations in the polymer [Greig, J.B. JECFA]. Later the substance was found in a wide range of halophilic and halotolerant bacteria such as Ectothiorhodospira halochloris and Halomonas elongate. It is also isolated from the marine-derived Streptomyces sp. SA-3501 (Pyrostatin B)(Lentzen and Schwarz 2006; CRC-DNP 2009). Ectoine belongs to a group of natural compounds, termed compatible solutes, which can be defined as organic osmolytes that are accumulated by the cell in high concentrations without disturbing vital cellular functions and the correct folding of proteins (Klein, Schwarz et al. 2007). Ectoine is produced predominantly at very high salinities and confers resistance towards salt and temperature stress (Saum and Muller 2008; Sigma-Aldrich 2009). Ectoine will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, (or L-Hyoscaymine)  (CAS # 101-31-5), also known as (-)-atropine, is an alkaloid isolated from Atropa, Datura, Duboisia, Hyoscyamus, Anthocercis and Scopolia spp. , Mandragora officinarum and several other genera in the Solanaceae family (ChemID Plus,  DNP, Leete et al 1954, O'Neil 2009, NHP ID). The racemization of hyoscyamine to atropine is known to occur by heating or by treatment with alkalis during extraction (Broadley 1996) or after ingestion (Beyer J). Hyoscyamine is used as an antispasmodic agent and is also an antimuscarinic agent with almost twice potency of atropine (O'Neil 2009, DNP).  It has also been used medicinally as anticholinergic agent (Yun 1992).Atropine and its salts are listed under the Schedule F:Atropine and its salts in ophthalmic or parenteral preparations only. Hyoscyamine will meet the definition of an NHP only in oral or topical dosage forms; not in ophthalmic or parenteral preparations which are on Schedule F and therefore, it is considered as an NHP, under item 2 (isolate) of the Schedule 1 of the NHP regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82450";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Hyoscyamine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195443;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:31:"Glutamic acid hydrochloride_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195443";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93158";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:244:"Glutamic acid HCl, is already classified as an acceptable source for Glutamic acid (an NHP). It is often used as a source for orotic acid (Sweetman 2009). It is also advertised as a source of zinc too. Based on human data of plasma concentration, compared to zinc pantothenate and zinc sulfate, it has a faster distribution and elimination phase from parenteral administration, and a slower absorption phase when administered orally (Andermann 1982). It is stated to liberate tannic acid in the gastrointestinal tract (Sweetman 2009). Albumin tannate contains 50% tannic acid (Pei-Show 2001). Albumin tannate is also considered as a source for both Albumin and Tannic acid (NHP Combination). (or N-Methylphenethylamine, Fig. 2) is a secondary amine found in Acacia spp., such as in Acacia adunca, Acacia berlandieri and Acacia rigidula; as well as in other spp., such as Dolichothele It is used as flavouring agent (JECFA). It is also known to have medicinal properties, including anti-bacterial, antifungal, andanti-inflammatory properties (DNP, Hart 2000).
Terpinen-4-ol will be considered as an NHP, under item 2 (isolate) of Schedule 1 of the NHP regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82460";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:13:"Terpinen-4-ol";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195452;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:15:"Artemisinin_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195452";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93226";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:497:"Artemisinin (US-NLM 2009) is an active anti-malarial constituent of the traditional Chinese medicinal herb Artemisia annua L., which has been known for almost 2000 years as 'Qinghaosu' (CRC-DNP 2009). It isolated in 1972 and shown to be a sesquiterpene lactone with a peroxide moiety (Merck 2009). Artemisinin combination treatments are now first-line drugs for uncomplicated falciparum malaria (White 2008). Artemisinin will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82461";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Artemisinin";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195453;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:10:"Gluten_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195453";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93256";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1095:"Gluten is the proteinaceous mass that remains when wheat (or barley or rye) dough is washed under a stream of water.  It is composed of about 75% proteins on a dry basis, with the remainder being starch, lipids and carbohydrates.  The protein fraction, which in practice the term 'gluten' refers to, is characterized by numerous protein components present as monomers or oligomers and polymers linked by interchain disulfide bonds; the alcohol-water soluble gliadins and insoluble glutenins, type of proteins called prolamins.  Gluten, which is present in or intermixed with the starchy endosperm of the grain, is used as an adhesive and substitute for flour; while medicinally, it is mainly associated with the coeliac disease, as patients with this disease are sensitive to its protein fraction (O'Neil et al. 2009, Sweetman 2009, Wieser 2007, Anjum et al. 2007, Shewry et al. 2002).  Based on the information presented above, Gluten does meet the substance aspect of the NHP definition, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Extract), as outlined in the NHP Regulations (Justice Canada 2009).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract ) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82462";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:6:"Gluten";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195454;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:10:"Glutin_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195454";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93256";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:421:"Glutin is a constituent of gluten, a proteinaceous mass from wheat, obtained when gluten is dissolved in alcohol; and therefore, a synonym for the gliadins portion of gluten (O'Neil et al. 2009, Gmelin and Watts 1871, Bell 1883, Johnston 1847). Consequently, Glutin meets the substance aspect of the NHP definition, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Extract), as outlined in the NHP Regulations (Justice Canada 2009).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract ) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82463";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:6:"Glutin";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195455;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:21:"N-Acetylcarnosine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195455";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93249";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:630:"N-Acetylcarnosine (US-NLM 2009) exists in the cardiac and skeletal mammalian muscles (Odowd, Robins et al. 1988; Babizhayev, Deyev et al. 2001) and also in the brain (Sobue, Konishi et al. 1975). N-Acetylcarnosine, as a bioactivating antioxidant, is a potent agent with the pleiotropic effects for ophthalmic therapy of senile cataracts and diabetic ocular complications (Babizhayev, Guiotto et al. 2009). N-Acetylcarnosine is also showed to be a prodrug of L-Carnosine (Babizhayev, Yermakova et al. 1996). N-Acetylcarnosine will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate and the source for Carnosine).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82464";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"N-Acetylcarnosine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195456;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:27:"Inositol hexanicotinate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195456";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92628";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:407:"Since Inositol niacinate is a synthetic compound, used as a peripheral vasodilatator and as a niacin supplement, which is prepared starting from two naturally occurring molecule, namely Nicotinic acid (niacin) and Inositol. In supplementation, Citruline ethyl ester has been used as a source of Citrulline assuming its dissociation to the free form in the body by hydrolysis or by esterases (enzymes which cleaves esters). The racemic form DL is used for treating vestibular-related imbalance, vertigo, and as an antiemetic (CRC-DNP 2009) (Sweetman 2009) (Merck 2009). The exact mechanism for the anti-vertigo property of N-Acetyl-DL-Leucine is unknown (Przybyski 2008). However, such this activity (i.e. anti-vertigo) does not establish for N-Acetyl-L-Leucine. Several different acylases (aminoacylases) are present in the body and supplied N-Acetylleucine, could thus be expected to be deacetylated and used as a source of Leucine. N-Acertylleucine will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (source of Leucine).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82473";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"N-Acetylleucine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195465;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:25:"N-Acetyl-L-isoleucine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195465";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93166";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:496:"N-Acetylisoleuice is the acetylated (amide) form of amino acid isoleucine (CRC-DNP 2009; US-NLM 2009). It produced by Streptomyces avermitilis (Nemecek, Novak et al. 1992). N-Acetylisoleuice also found in Mycobacterium ranae (Fowler, Dunn et al. 1961). Aminoacylases are capable of hydrolysis of N-Acetylisoleucine to isoleucine (Kiba, Oyama et al. 1995). N-Acetylisoleucine will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate and the source for the amino acid isoleucine).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82474";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:21:"N-Acetyl-L-isoleucine";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195466;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:28:"beta-Alanine ethyl ester_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195466";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93166";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:664:"ß-Alanine ethyl ester is a derivative of amino acid ß-Alanine (CRC-DNP 2009) (US-NLM 2009). Many amino acid supplements containing this ingredient are currently used. N-Acetylphenylalanine appears in large amount in urine of patients with phenylketonuria (a human genetic disorder due to the lack of enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase). N-Acetylphenylalanine is a product of enzyme phenylalanine N-acetyltransferase in the pathway phenylalanine metabolism (Okajima, Inoue et al. 1985). N-Acetylphenylalanine is a non-translocated substrate for the mammalian peptide transporter PepT1 expressed in Xenopus laevis oocytes (Meredith 2002). Several different acylases (aminoacylases) are present in the body and supplied N-Acetylphenylalanine could thus be expected to be deacetylated and used as a source of phenylalanine. Natto is a fermented cheese-like food that has been used in Japan for over 1000 years for its popular taste and as a folk remedy for heart and vascular diseases. It will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82485";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Nattokinase";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195476;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:11:"Muscone_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195476";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93344";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1186:"Muscone (Fig. 1), in its naturally occurring R(-)-form, is the odorous principle of musk, the dried secretions from the preputial follicles of the musk deer, Moschus moschiferus; and other species, such as the Chinese civet (Veverricula Indica) and the muskrat (Ondatra zibethica) (DNP 2009, NAPRALERTsm 2009, O'Neil et al. 2009, Sweetman 2009).  Muscone has shown experimentally to induce rats liver microsomal cytochrome P450, suggesting potential interactions with other drugs activity and metabolism (Peng et al. 1986, Tanaka et al. 1987, Tanaka et al. 1991).  As a macrocyclic ketone and due to the presence of one chiral center, Muscone has been the target of many racemic and asymmetric syntheses (Blomquist et al. 1948, Nicolaou and Pfefferkorn 2001, Fujimoto et al. 2002, Ito et al. 2005, Erden et al. 2008); as well as the subject of isolation and assay methods apparently due to its increasing use in pharmaceutical preparations (Paik and Kim 2004).  As a naturally occurring substance, Muscone (in its R(-)-form, as well as its synthetic duplicate or racemate forms) meets the substance aspect of the NHP definition, as outlined in the NHP Regulations (Justice Canada 2009).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82486";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:7:"Muscone";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195477;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:36:"Secoisolariciresinol diglucoside_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195477";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93347";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1037:"Secoisolariciresinol diglucoside,(CAS #: 148244-82-0) is an important releasable lignan present in Flaxseeds, in amounts significantly higher (60-700 times) than in other edible plant materials (ChemID Plus, Ford 2001). It was initially isolated from flaxseed and identified in 1947 (Ford 2001) and since then many variations of this isolation have been proposed, using mixtures of different solvents, including methanol, chloroform and water (Frank 2004). Lignans found in Flaxseed (including secoisolariciresinol diglucoside) have been reported to possess phyto-oestrogenic, anticarcinogenic and anti-atherogenic effects (Frank 2004). Secoisolariciresinol diglucoside is specifically known to be a natural cancer chemopreventive agent against breast, prostate and colon cancers. It is metabolized into mammalian lignans enterodiol and enterolactone through the effects of anaerobic fecal microflora (Ford 2001). Secoisolariciresinol diglucoside will be considered as an NHP, under item 2 (isolate) of Schedule 1 of the NHP regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82487";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:32:"Secoisolariciresinol diglucoside";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195478;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:17:"Tocophersolan_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195478";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93366";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2397:"alpha-Tocopheryl polyethylene glycol succinate (TPGS, Fig. 1) is an esterified water-soluble vitamin E derivative, mainly used as a non-medicinal ingredient for its surfactant properties (e.g. as absorption enhancer, emulsifying agent, solubilizing agent) in pharmaceutical preparations; also medicinally as a source of vitamin E (Kibbe 2009, Sweetman 2009, USPD 2009). In vitro experiments using human fibroblasts, erythrocytes, or Caco-2 cells have demonstrated TPGS to be taking up as an intact molecule and subsequently be hydrolyzed slowly intracellularly (Traber et al. 1988).  These results have also been demonstrated by Youk et al. (2005) in human lung cancer cell lines, in addition to the observed improved anticancer efficacy compared to alpha-tocopherol succinate due to its increased ability to induce reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation and cell apoptosis in relevant doses.  Consequently to these results, as well as because of its amphiphilic and water solubility nature, TPGS has been studied and showed positive results as an absorption and bioavailability enhancer or vehicle for anticancer drugs, such as camptothecin, paclitaxel, and doxorubicin (Mu et al. 2005, Dong et al. 2008, Ho et al. 2008, Cao and Feng 2008); observations also correlated to its P-glycoprotein inhibition properties (Dintaman and Silverman 1999). Clinically, TPGS has been shown to normalize serum vitamin E levels and improve neurological development, but not improving the increased lipid peroxidation and poor polyunsaturated fatty acids status; after oral administration in cholestatic children (Socha et al. 1997). The information outlined above suggests that TPGS can be used as a source of vitamin E, as this molecule, at least in part, showed to be hydrolyzed to its parent NHP substance; consistent with other tocopherol esters (Fiume 2002).  Consequently, alpha-Tocopheryl polyethylene glycol succinate will be considered as a source of vitamin E and therefore, an NHP.  Note that 'Vitamin E polyethylene glycol succinate' (CAS# 9002-96-4), as a mixture consisting primarily of the mono-esterified polyethylene glycol and a small amount of di-esterified polyethylene glycol, seems to be the main substance used as NMI, whereas the above-mentioned substance seems to be a more purified form, most probably more used for medicinal purposes (Kibbe 2009, NIH 2009, USP/NF 2009, USPD 2009).)";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 3 (a vitamin) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:110:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 3 (une vitamine) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82488";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:13:"Tocophersolan";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"VIT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195479;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:16:"Dexpanthenol_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195479";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93338";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1456:"Dexpanthenol is a synthetic product, reasonably stable under usual sterilization times and temperatures in aqueous solution adjusted to pH 3.0-4.0. However, long heating causes racemization. Dexpanthenol’s natural pH is about 9.5 and it can be hydrolyzed by alkali and strong acid. Panthenol is more stable than pure pantothenic acid, highly soluble in water and rapidly converted to the free acid within the body. It is also more stable than salts of pantothenic acid if the pH can be adjusted to between 3 and 5. Despite the fact that Dexpanthenol’s mechanism of action is unknown, it is readily converted to and excreted as pantothenic acid after oral or parenteral administration, and it is widely distributed into body tissues, mainly as coenzyme A. Dextropantothenyl alcohol has been used topically in the treatment of burns, wounds, decubitus ulcers, eczema, contact dermatitis and pruritus. It has also been used in treatment of lupus erythematosus. The topical use of Dexpanthenol, the stable alcoholic analog of pantothenic acid, is based on good skin penetration and high local concentrations of Dexpanthenol when administered in an adequate vehicle, such as a water-in-oil emulsion. Since Dexpanthenol is readily converted to and excreted as pantothenic acid after oral or parenteral administration, it will be considered as a source of pantothenic acid and therefore it is an NHP that falls under item 3, Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 3 (a vitamin) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:110:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 3 (une vitamine) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82490";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Dexpanthenol";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"VIT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195480;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:19:"Anthocyanosides_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195480";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93371";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:329:"Anthocyanins are naturally occurring compounds that impart color to fruit, vegetables, and plants.They are often observed in the plant kingdom, where they serve to color anything from fruits to the autumn leaves. It is used as an antimicrobial preservative in cosmetics, food products, and pharmaceutical formulations (Gottschalck and Bailey 2008). Benzylparaben is hydrolyzed to 4-hydroxybenzoic acid in different parts of the body (Jewell, Prusakiewicz et al. 2007). Many other 4-hydroxybenzoic acid esters, such as methyl ester (Methyparaben), ethyl ester (Ethylparaben), butyl ester (Butylparaben) are naturally occurring materials (CRC-DNP 2009). Benzylparaben although not natural, but due to being a source for 4-hydroxybenzoic acid and similar properties with other natural parabens will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82492";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:13:"Benzylparaben";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195482;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:18:"Diethanolamine_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195482";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93271;92722";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:690:"Diethanolamine (Fig. 1) is a secondary amine manufactured commercially by the ammonolysis of ethylene oxide; mainly used, in relation to its pharmaceutical non-medicinal ingredient applications, as a buffering agent, alkalizing agent, emulsifying agent, pH adjuster, dispersant, and/or stabilizing agent (Kibbe 2009, O'Neil et al. 2009, Sweetman 2009). les produits de santé Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:37:"L-Norvaline ethyl ester hydrochloride";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195487;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:20:"Dihydromyricetin_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195487";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93428";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:815:"Dihydromyricetin (CAS #: 27200-12-0) is a flavonoid found in leaves of Ampelopsis meliaefolia, from bark of Pinus contoria, from Erythrophleum africanum ( ChemID Plus, O'Neil 2009, Zhang Y 2007). It is considered to be one of the main bioactive ingredients of Ampelopsis grossedentata (Rattan Tea), present in the range of 20-30%(w/w) in the tender stems and leaves of the plant (Zhang YS 2007). It is known for its antioxidant properties (Yang 2008). It has also been shown to have an antagonistic action to arterial systole reaction caused by arterenol and a high concentration of potassium ions, and medical activities in antiphlogosis, relieving cough, decreasing blood-fat, and protecting the liver (Li 2008). Dihydromyricetin will be considered as an NHP, under item 2 (isolate) of Schedule 1 of the NHP regs.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82502";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Dihydromyricetin";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195488;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Coumarin_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195488";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92863";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1484:"Coumarin is a benzopyrone compound. It has a pleasant, fragrant odor resembling that of vanilla beans with burning taste. It occurs in tonka beans, lavender oil, woodruff (Asperula species), in sweet clover (Melilotus) [1-2]. It also found in Cinnamons especially 'Cassia' (Cinnamomum aromaticum) [3]. Coumarin is used extensively in perfumery. It is an antineoplastic, antiinflammatory, antihyperglycaemic agent and  used for treatment of lymphoedema; as herbicide; as inhibitor of cellulose synthetase. It also shows antiprotozoal and antimalarial properties [2]. Coumarin will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).Both Cassia cinnamon (chinese cinnamon) and Ceylon cinnamon are acceptable as NHP which contain coumarin and the amount of coumarin in Cassia is much higher than other type of cinnamon . However, the amount of coumarin in cinnamon does not normally pose a risk for NHPs because the level of consumption is limited. The only federal regulatory which set a limit for coumarin (cinnamon) is Germany [4]; 'Tolerable Daily Intake (TDI) for coumarin= 0.1mg/kg b.w.' which means 7 mg/day for adult based on 70 kg body weight. Each gram of Cassia cinnamon powder contains 2.1-4.4 mg coumarin; therefore, the safest amount of acceptable Cassia would be 1.6 g/day according to the TDI (Germany).P.S. "NHPD has no limits for Coumarin.  However, any dose would have to be supported by safety and efficacy data during assessment before approval."";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82503";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Coumarin";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195489;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:49:"Oligosaccharide 4-alpha-D-glucosyltransferase_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195489";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92760";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:460:"According to the Enzyme Nomenclature database [2], this oligosaccharide ‘transfers the non-reducing terminal alpha-D-glucose residue from a (1->4)-alpha-D-glucan to the 4-position of an alpha-D-glucan, thus bringing about the hydrolysis of oligosaccharides’[1].
