les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82511";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Plant sterol esters";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195497;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:21:"Creatine pyruvate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195497";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92811";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2663:"Creatine pyruvate is an organic salt formed between creatine and pyruvic acid. Apparently, this molecule exists in different molar ratios (e.g. 1:1, 1:2, 2:1), in anhydrous or hydrate forms (e.g. 0 to 10 moles of water), and can be synthesized at different temperatures (e.g. 10 to 30 oC) and in different solvents (e.g. alcohols, ethers, ketones, esters or mixtures). Even though the resulting compound would preferably contain a molar ratio of 1:1 (meaning about 60% creatine and 40% pyruvic acid), it is believed to be of relative purity, as it could also be a mixture of different ratio salts with or without unreacted creatine and pyruvic acid (Fang 1999, Pischel et al. 2000, Pischel et al. 2001). In terms of efficacy of Creatine pyruvate as compared to placebo or other creatine compounds (e.g. creatine monohydrate and creatine citrate), the available studies showed mixed results. For example, Creatine pyruvate (7 g per day for 7 days) did not have an impact on endurance capacity or intermittent sprint performance in trained cyclists as compared to placebo (Schuylenbergh R.V. et al. 2003), whereas a beneficial effect on performance during high intensity exercice was observed following the administration of Creatine pyruvate (5 g per day for 28 days) as compared to placebo with slightly better results than creatine citrate (Jager R. et al. 2008). Negative results (i.e. no additional advantage observed with the pyruvate combination) were also observed after 5 weeks creatine and pyruvate supplementation on anaerobic performance and body composition in football players, as compared to creatine monohydrate and calcium pyruvate alone (Stone M.H. et al. 1999). Following isomolar administration of Creatine pyruvate, creatine monohydrate, and creatine citrate, a pharmacokinetic study showed an increase in creatine plasma concentrations in all treatments and all doses, but with slithly higher concentrations of creatine with Creatine pyruvate (Jager R. et al. 2007). These studies show that the safety & efficacy profile, as well as the pharmacokinetics parameters, of Creatine pyruvate are still to be investigated. However, the consensus, at least theoretically, is that the beneficial effects (if any) of Creatine pyruvate, as compared to placebo or other creatine compounds, would be due to the combined effects of creatine and pyruvate individually, as it is expected that this molecule splits into its components in the acid environment of the stomach after ingestion. For this reason, Creatine pyruvate will be considered as a source of two naturally occurring substances, namely creatine and pyruvic acid (DNP 2009); therefore, an NHP.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82521";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:26:"d-alpha Tocopheryl acetate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195507;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:11:"Olaflur_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195507";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93523";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1163:"Olaflur (amine fluoride 297 or AmF) (US-NLM 2009) is an anticariogenic organic amine fluoride which often used in combination with stannous fluoride (SnF2) or sodium fluoride. It reduces surface tension of saliva, forming a protective film on tooth surfaces (Merck 2009). Olaflur is used as a source of fluoride (Sweetman 2009).Toothpastes containing the AmF/SnF2 complex have antimicrobial properties due to the amine and stannous parts and are well known for their inhibitory effects on growth of oral microorganisms and for the retardation of plaque growth. Moreover, the additional use of AmF/SnF2 mouthwash after brushing is effective in reducing the acid metabolism in dental plaque and tongue flora (Gerardu, van Loveren et al. 2006). In a recent study, at the same concentrations, acidic SnF2 and AmF (pH= 3.9) were shown to be more effective than NaF to protect enamel against erosion. Thus, the hypothesis that the different fluoride solutions will not differ in their potential to reduce enamel erosion is rejected (Wiegand, Bichsel et al. 2009). Olaflur will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 7 (mineral), Priority 1 (source of Fluoride).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82522";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:7:"Olaflur";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195508;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:37:"Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195508";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93562";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:441:"NAD (for Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide), one of the bioactive forms of nicotinic acid, is a coenzyme widely distributed in living cells which serves as an hydrogen acceptor, forming NADH which then serves as a hydrogen donor in the respiratory chain.  Since Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide can be found in cells of living organisms, it will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82523";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:33:"Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195509;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:16:"Benzoic Acid_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195509";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92847";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1066:"Benzoic acid is the simplest aromatic carboxylic acid, which can be found in nature in its free form or as its combined forms.  For exemple, gum benzoin, which is the balsamic resin obtained from the bark of several species of trees in the genus Styrax, is known to contain up to 20% free benzoic acid and up to 40% benzoic acid esters, which is why gum resin was for a long time the only source of benzoic acid.  Now a days, Benzoic acid is commercially synthetized using the oxidation of toluene.  Benzoic acid (also as its sodium, calcium and potassium salts) is a well known preservative (which is why it is listed in the NHPD acceptable NMIs list) and is also used, mostly in combination with salicylic acid, as a topical antifungal, since Benzoic acid have the properties of inhibiting the growth of mold, yeast and certain bacteria.  Its sodium salt, sodium benzoate, is already classified in the database as a Priority 2 NHP.  For these reasons, Benzoic acid will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82524";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Benzoic Acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195510;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:32:"Magnesium phosphate, dibasic_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195510";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93566";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:305:"Magnesium phosphate, dibasic is found in nature as its trihydrate form, under the mineral names newberyite, phosphor-roesslerite. succinate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195513";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93531";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:460:"Ammonium succinate is ammonium salt of succinic acid (NIH 2009).  This substance has been used experimentally as a source for both ammonium and succinate, and shown to normalize adenine nucleotides in old rats (Kaminsky et al. 1983).  As such, Ammonium succinate is interpreted as an acceptable derivative and consequently, as meeting the substance aspect of the natural health product definition, as outlined in the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2009)";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82529";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Ammonium succinate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195514;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:11:"Silybin_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195514";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93603";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:691:"Silybin is a flavolignan that has been isolated as a mixture of two diastereoisomers, Silybin A and B, from the fruit or seeds of milk thistle, Silybum marianum (DNP 2009, NAPRALERTsm 2009, O’Neil et al. 2009).
This compound that is isolated or as a standardized extract of Silybum marianum called silymarin, has shown experimentally and/or clinically a potential for its use in a wide range of applications, due to its hepatoprotective, chemoprotective, neuroprotective, and other effects (Kren and Walterova 2005).

It is known to possess antiinflammatory, antineoplastic, antifungal, analgesic and antioxidant properties (DNP, Chem ID, Sheu 2009, Theriault 2000).
Taxifolin will be considered as an NHP, under item 2 (isolate) of Schedule 1 of the NHP regulations.

Turkesterone does not bind to the cytosolic steroid receptors, instead, it is likely to influence signal transduction pathways, like the anabolic steroids, possibly via membrane bound receptors. The hydrolysis of inulin by inulase produces fructose, through a single step method, and this method is used to make high fructose syrup (Singh et al. 2006).     Crude tannic acid administered orally has been associated with hepatotoxicity, while certain ellagitannin isolates may protect against hepatotoxicity. phosphopeptide- amorphous calcium phosphate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195550";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94772";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:913:"Casein phosphopeptide- amorphous calcium phosphate (CPP-ACP) is a complex delivering calcium and phosphate to the teeth enamel in a stable manner, then promotes remineralization. The peptide part (CPP) maintains calcium and phosphate in an amorphous, soluble form, and binds to the surface of the tooth thus presenting this soluble calcium phosphate at a high concentration to promote remineralization [1]. At the same time, it also prevents demineralization of teeth [2].
In a recent study, CPP-ACP sugar-free gum significantly slowed progression and enhanced regression of approximal caries relative to a control sugar-free gum [3]. Since every parts of the CPP-ACP complex are considered natural, the combination of these NHPs, i.e. Casein phosphopeptide- amorphous calcium phosphate, will be considered as a NHP, and also as a source for calcium and phosphorus, under schedule 1, item 7, Priority 5 (mineral).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82568";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:50:"Casein phosphopeptide- amorphous calcium phosphate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195551;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:21:"Hydrolyzed casein_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195551";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94772";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:371:"Casein hydrolysate (or Casein peptides) is the break-down product of Casein protein, the predominant protein found in fresh milk.  It is composed essentially of different small peptide units, containing various essential and non-essential amino acids.  Casein hydrolysate will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (Priority 2; Isolate) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82569";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Hydrolyzed casein";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195552;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:12:"Smectite_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195552";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94562";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:657:"Smectites are natural aluminum silicate mineral clays, from which the most common members are montmorillonite, nontronite, and saponite (Mindat 2010, Sweetman 2010). Some smectites, such as dioctahedral smectite, have been used in the management of diarrhea, and as antacid (PharmaSuisse 2008, Sweetman 2010). Smectites are also used as excipients, for example hectorite and saponite used as absorbent, emulsifying, and viscosity-increasing agent (Rowe et al. 2009). Based on the above, Smectites meet the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 7 (mineral) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:100:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 7 (a mineral) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82570";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Smectite";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195553;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:21:"Calcium caprylate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195553";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94560";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:617:"Calcium caprylate is the 1:2 calcium salt of caprylic acid, a substance found in and isolated from many plant oils (DNP 2010, NAPRALERTsm 2010, NIH 2010). Similar to caprylic acid, calcium caprylate has antifungal activity (Sweetman 2010). Calcium caprylate is also used as a binder, emulsifier, and anticaking agent in foods (Yannai 2004, Smith and Hong-Shum 2003).Based on the above, it is believed that calcium caprylate has the potential to act as a source ingredient for caprylic acid, a substance falling under Schedule 1, item 2 (isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82571";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Calcium caprylate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195554;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:23:"Magnesium caprylate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195554";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94560";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:628:"Magnesium caprylate is the 1:2 magnesium salt of caprylic acid, a substance found in and isolated from many plant oils (DNP 2010, NAPRALERTsm 2010, NIH 2010). Similar to caprylic acid, magnesium caprylate has antifungal activity (Sweetman 2010). Magnesium caprylate is also used as a binder, emulsifier, and anticaking agent in foods (Yannai 2004, Smith and Hong-Shum 2003). Based on the above, it is believed that magnesium caprylate has the potential to act as a source ingredient for caprylic acid, a substance falling under Schedule 1, item 2 (isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82572";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Magnesium caprylate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195555;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:18:"Zinc caprylate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195555";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94560";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:699:"Zinc caprylate is the 1:2 zinc salt of caprylic acid, a substance found in and isolated from many plant oils (DNP 2010, NAPRALERTsm 2010, NIH 2010, O’Neil et al. 2010). The structure of pure anhydrous zinc caprylate consists of polymeric parallel sheets (Lacouture et al. 2000). Similar to caprylic acid, zinc caprylate has antifungal activity (O’Neil et al. 2010, Sweetman 2010). Zinc caprylate is also used as PVC stabilizer (Kirk-Othmer 2010). Based on the above, it is believed that zinc caprylate has the potential to act as a source ingredient for caprylic acid, a substance falling under Schedule 1, item 2 (isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82573";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:14:"Zinc caprylate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195556;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:18:"Procyanidin B2_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195556";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94852";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:593:"Procyanidins are derivatives of the flavan-3-o1 class of flavonoids. This class includes (+)-catechin, commonly referred to as catechin, and (-)-epicatechin, commonly referred to as epicatechin. Procyanidins are dimers and oligomers of catechin and epicatechin and their gallic acid esters. Procyanidins are widely distributed in the plant kingdom and are found in grape seeds, cocoa, chocolate, apples, peanuts, almonds, cranberries, blueberries and in the bark of pines, among other plant sources. Procyanidin B-2 will be considered as an NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82574";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:14:"Procyanidin B2";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195557;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:15:"Sierra clay_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195557";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94548";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:594:"Sierra clay is a natural mineral from the Sierra Mountains, Nevada, USA (Bailey 1945, USDA 1906). exists in milk as large colloidal particles called casein micelles, which are spherical particles with a mean radius of 80 nm, composed of four different casein molecules (αs1-, αs2-, β-, and Small modifications to fatty acids mean esterification.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract ) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82600";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:21:"Cetylated fatty acids";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195581;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:23:"Hyodeoxycholic acid_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195581";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95075";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:656:"Hyodeoxycholic acid is a bile acid isolated from pig bile (Sacquet et al. 1983, O’Neil et al. 2010). It was also isolated from chicks (Haslewood 1971). Recently, Hyodeoxycholic acid was isolated from human plasma and quantified (Xiang et al. 2010). Some researchers showed that Hyodeoxycholic acid can reduce the formation of cholesterol and cholesterol-induced gallstones in animals (Sehayek et al. 2001, Cohen-Solal et al. 1995, Singhal et al. 1984). Based on the above, Hyodeoxycholic acid meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 2 (isolate) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82601";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Hyodeoxycholic acid";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195582;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:23:"Tricreatine citrate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195582";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95131";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:279:"Tricreatine citrate is the Creatine salt (3:1) of Citric acid. It will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82602";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Tricreatine citrate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195583;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:29:"8'-Apo-beta-caroten-8'-al_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195583";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95330";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1199:"This carotenoid is believed to be an intermediate in at least one of the metabolism pathways of β-carotene to vitamin A retinoids; and consequently, considered as a pro-vitamin A carotenoid (Ho et al. 2007, Wang et al. 1992).  Other than its vitamin A activity, β-Carotinal has shown, experimentally in rats and mice, to possess activities which β-carotene lacks, such as the relative ability to induce liver xenobiotic-metabolizing enzymes (Astorg et al. 1997, Gradelet et al. 1997).  Furthermore, pharmacokinetic studies in human suggested that, in addition to its possible direct vitamin A retinoids pathway, β-Carotinal is converted to its corresponding acid (also found in dogs), alcohol, and fatty acyl ester. Ultimately, it could also result in vitamin A retinoids (Zeng et al. 1992, Bagdon et al. 1962). Based on the above, β-Carotinal meets the substance aspect of the natural health product definition, under Schedule 1, item 2 (isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).  However, it is not considered as a source ingredient for β-carotene, based on the definition of derivatives in the Product Licensing Guidance Document (Health Canada 2006).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82603";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:25:"8'-Apo-beta-caroten-8'-al";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195584;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:24:"Xylooligosaccharides_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195584";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95117";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1011:"Xylooligosaccharides are oligomers of xylose units, produced by the chemical, enzymatic and/or thermal hydrolysis of lignocellulosic materials such hardwoods, corncobs, and bran. These oligosaccharides are mainly composed of two or three xylose units with β-1,4-linkages (Akpinar et al. 2009, Vazquez et al. 2000). They have been shown to possess a variety of health-related effects, such as improving sugar and lipids levels in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus, inhibiting the development of precancerous lesions, promoting the growth of Bifidobacterium, and lowering the cecal pH in rats (Sheu et al. 2008, Hsu et al. 2004). Xylooligosaccharides also normalize bowel movement in pregnant women by regulating intestinal flora and increasing the intestinal contents (Tateyama et al. 2005).Based on the above, Xylooligosaccharides meet the substance aspect of the natural health product definition, under Schedule 1, item 2 (extract) of the Natural Health Products Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract ) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82604";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Xylooligosaccharides";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195585;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:25:"Glyceryl monostearate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195585";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94362";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1276:"Glyceryl monostearate is an ester prepared from the reaction of glycerine with the triglycerides from animal or vegetable sources or by the reaction of glycerine with stearoyl chloride (NIH 2010, Rowe et al. 2009). It has been used in pharmaceutical dispensing, cosmetics, and foods as emollient, emulsifying agent, solubilising agent, stabilizing agent, sustained-release agent, and tablet/capsule lubricant (O’Neil et al. 2010, PCPC 2010, Smith and Hong-Shum 2003, Sweetman 2010).It was reported that Glyceryl monostearate was isolated from cultures of Penicillium sp. (DNP 2010, Harri et al. 1963). The original report on the naturally occurring form of glyceryl monostearate was closely investigated. A considerable consistency between the isolated substance in the report and authentic samples (such as IR spectrum, melting point, and elemental analysis) was found (Discussion 2010). It is noteworthy to mention that Glyceryl monostearate, identified as 1-_O_-Stearylglycerin (α-Monostearin) in the article, has been reported by Harri et al. (1963) as a by-product.Based on the above, glyceryl monostearate meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 2 (isolate) of the NHP Regulations is a naturally-occurring food additive. It is a lactone (cyclic ester) of D-gluconic acid. Biological oxidation of glucose at the C1 position yield δ-gluconolactone. The extent to which δ-gluconolactone is hydrolyzed to nondissociated gluconic acid and gluconate is strongly pH dependent.

Pterostilbene is the dimethyl ether analog of Resveratrol.

Some of the best sources of caffeic acid are grapes, wine, and coffee. Caffeic acid is one of the hydroxycinnamic acids, which are the most widely dispersed class of phenylpropanoids in plants, and which also include ferulic acid and coumaric acid.
Caffeic acid will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.

Tracheloside will be considered a NHP under Schedule 1, item 2, (isolate)of the Natural Health Products Regulations.

During the extraction process the mannoproteins in the surface of the cell walls can be removed in order to obtain a highly purified preparation of which the beta-1,3/1,6-glucans are exposed for optimum bioactivity. It will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (extract) of the NHP Regulations.

Glucose and fructose are isolates.According to USP, high fructose corn syrup is available in two types: 1) High Fructose Corn Syrup 42%, in which about 42% of total solids is fructose, 2) High Fructose Corn Syrup 55%, in which about 55% of total solids is fructose.

Creatine ethyl ester is probably more soluble than creatine monohydrate or other forms of creatine.
Creatine ethyl ester hydrochloride could be synthesized by treatment of anhydrous creatine with ethanolic HCl at room temperature and also by acid-catalyzed esterification of creatine monohyrdate.

Berberine hydrochloride is an isoquinoline alkaloid and exists as a quaternary ammonium cation in aqueous solution; it is present, usually as a hydrochloride or sulphate, in the roots, rhizomes and stem bark of various plants[Liu&Kong 2003]. These plants include Hydrastis canadensis (goldenseal), Coptis chinensis (goldenthread), Berberis aquifolium (Oregon grape), and Berberis vulgaris (barberry)[Natural Standards 2010]. Berberine hydrochloride has antimicrobial activity against bacteria, fungi, and viruses[Natural Standards 2010].
Berberine hydrochloride will be considered a NHP under Schedule 1, item 2, isolate, of the Natural Health Products Regulations.

The common method for the separation of rice protein from the starch of milled rice grains is by alkali solubilisation of the proteins followed by acid precipitation (Connor, Saunders, & Kohler, 1977; Yamamoto, Sumie, & Toshio, 1973). An alternative is to treat the flour or kernels with enzymes to partially remove the starch component. Rice protein concentrate can have high protein content (ranging from 60-80% or above).

FCC: Food Chemicals Codex, 7th edition. http://online.foodchemicalscodex.org/ online/";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract ) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82624";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Acid casein";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195604;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:28:"Milk protein concentrate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195604";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95445";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1234:"Milk protein concentrate is produced from skim milk using ultrafiltration and drying; some processes involve diafiltration also (Huffman and Harper 1999; Haque et al. 2010).  An upper limit for protein content is usually included in the definition, such as less than 85% (Haque et al. 2010); or less than 88% (UBIC Consulting 2010). However, because of the usual tolerances permitted in quality specifications, there is effectively no upper limit for protein content. Nonfat dry milk is 34% protein and the lower limit for protein content in milk protein concentrates is 40% protein (Huffman and Harper 1999, UBIC Consulting 2010).

It has, medicinally, mostly been used as a source of protein, in the treatment of children malnutrition for example (Sweetman 2010, Doraiswamy et al. 1962).

Electronic Version [Accessed 2010-04-30].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82626";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Calcium caseinate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195606;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:24:"Milk protein isolate_APN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195606";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95445";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1349:"Total protein isolate from milk contains both the casein and whey proteins (Rajagopalan and Cheryan 1991). In milk protein isolate the protein composition has “a substantially unaltered proportion of casein to whey proteins wherein the dry matter consists of greater than 85% milk protein” (Bhaskar et al. 2007). Another definition of milk protein isolate specifies 88% or higher protein content (UBIC Consulting 2010). Milk protein isolate can be produced from skim milk using a process that involves ultrafiltration, diafiltration, and drying (Huffman and Harper 1999). The name “milk protein isolate” is also applied to products with about 90% protein content produced from skim milk by a different method (Hoffman and Harper 1999).
References: 
Bhaskar GV, Singh H, Blazey ND. United States Patent 7,157,108. Milk Protein Products and Processes. January 2, 2007.

UBIC Consulting 2010. URL: http://www.ubic-consulting.com/template/fs/documents/Dairy-Ingredients/milkproteinconcentrate-tmp-ingredient-market.pdf";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract ) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82627";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Milk protein isolate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"APN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195607;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:28:"Isomaltulose monohydrate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195607";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95547";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1898:"Isomaltulose and its monohydrate are nutritive sweeteners (FCC 2010; FDA 2006). Crystals are the monohydrate (Merck Index). Although the monohydrate form is sometimes called isomaltulose (FDA 2006), isomaltulose is used as a name for the anhydrous form in CHEMID.
Isomaltulose is a disaccharide that is found in honey and in sugar cane juice (Lina et al. 2002). Isomaltulose is not recognized as a sweetener for foods in the Canadian Food and Drug Regulations (Table IX to section B16.100). However, isomaltulose is included in the Food Chemicals Codex (FCC 2010). The monohydrate form does have GRAS status in the United States for use as a nutritive sweetener “that would totally or partially replace sucrose…” (FDA 2006). Since isomaltulose is the form of the compound found in solution after the monohydrate is dissolved, both forms are permitted in food in the United States. In 2005 isomaltulose was authorized for sale as a novel food in the European Union, with the monohydrate as the commercial product (European Commission 2005). Isomaltulose has been a food in Japan since 1985 (Lina et al. 2002).

European Commission. 2005. Commission Decision 4 April 2005 authorising the placing on the market of isomaltulose as a novel food or novel food ingredient under Regulation (EC) No 258/97 of the European Parliament and of the Council (2005/457/EC). http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32005D0457:EN:NOT

Commercial product consists of 70-80% silymarin flavonolignans: silydianin, silychristin, diastereoisomers of silybin (silybin A and B), and diastereoisomers of isosilybin (isosilybin A and B)[MI]. Silybin, the major constituent of the therapeutic extract silymarin, exists as a mixture of diastereomers, silybin A and silybin B[MI; Lee et al 2003] and is entered in the NHPID as a Medicinal Ingredient.
As Silymarin is a flavolignan complex from a plant source, it will be considered a NHP under Schedule 1, item 2, extract, of the Natural Health Products Regulations.

HMB is a leucine metabolite produced in the body through oxidation of the ketoacid of leucine (ketoisocaproate). After leucine is metabolized to KIC, KIC is either metabolized into isovaleryl-CoA by the enzyme alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase in the mitochondria, or into beta-hydroxy-beta-methylbutyrate (HMB) in the cytosol, by the enzyme alpha-ketoisocaproate dioxygenase.
Calcium β-hydroxy-β-methylbutyrate acts as a source of β-hydroxy-β-methylbutyrate and therefore meets the definition of a NHP derivative, as defined in the Product Licensing guidance document.
Calcium beta-hydroxy-beta-methylbutyrate will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, (as an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:14:"Propagermanium";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195616;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:57:"Calcium-beta-hydroxy beta-methyl butyrate monohydrate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195616";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95947";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:947:"Calcium beta-hydroxy-beta-methylbutyrate is a nutritional supplement, which represents a calcium salt of beta-hydroxy beta-methylbutyrate (HMB). HMB is a leucine metabolite produced in the body through oxidation of the ketoacid of leucine (ketoisocaproate). After leucine is metabolized to KIC, KIC is either metabolized into isovaleryl-CoA by the enzyme alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase in the mitochondria, or into beta-hydroxy-beta-methylbutyrate (HMB) in the cytosol, by the enzyme alpha-ketoisocaproate dioxygenase.
HMB is currently marketed as calcium-HMB-monohydrate.
Calcium β-hydroxy-β-methylbutyrate monohydrate acts as a source of β-hydroxy-β-methylbutyrate and therefore meets the definition of a NHP derivative, as defined in the Product Licensing guidance document.
Calcium beta-hydroxy-beta-methylbutyrate monohydrate will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, (as an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82640";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:53:"Calcium-beta-hydroxy beta-methyl butyrate monohydrate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195617;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:34:"Calcium 4-methyl-2-oxovalerate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195617";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"96136";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:411:"Calcium ketoisocaproate is the Calcium salt of alpha-Ketoisocaproic acid.
Commercially, Calcium ketoisocaproate is used as a source of alpha-Ketoisocaproic acid, which is classified as an NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (isolate) of the Natural Health Product Regulations.
Calcium salt of ketoisocaproic acid will be considered an NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (isolate) of the Natural Health Product Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82641";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:30:"Calcium 4-methyl-2-oxovalerate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195618;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:17:"Glucoraphanin_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195618";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95953";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:493:"Glucoraphanin which is also know as sulforaphane glucosinolates is the glucosinolate precursor of sulforaphane. Broccoli sprouts contain high concentrations of sulforaphane glucosinolates. Sulforaphane is released when sulforaphane glucosinolate undergoes hydrolysis by myrosinase released from plant tissues during the chewing process.
Glucoraphanin (sulforaphane glucosinolate) will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (as an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82642";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:13:"Glucoraphanin";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195619;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:36:"Potassium 4-methyl-2-oxovalerate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195619";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"95283";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1357:"The Natural Health Products Ingredients Database (NHPID) indicates that 4-methyl-2-oxovaleric acid (synonym: alpha-ketoisocaproic acid) is classified as an NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (isolate) of the Natural Health Product Regulations, and has an NMI role as flavour enhancer. Potassium 4-methyl-2-oxovalerate is the potassium salt of 4-methyl-2-oxovaleric acid. The sodium salt of 4-methyl-2-oxovaleric acid is included in NHPID with the NHPID name 4-Methyl-2-oxopentanoic acid, sodium salt and CAS RN 4502-00-5. Synonyms for the sodium salt include sodium 4-methyl-2-oxovalerate, sodium alpha-ketoisocaproate and 4-methyl-2-oxovaleric acid, sodium salt [CHEMID; JECFA]. NHPID indicates that sodium 4-methyl-2-oxovalerate has the NMI role of flavour enhancer, but does not indicate whether it is considered an NHP. The compound 4-methyl-2-oxovaleric acid is present in male rats (Grootegoed et al. 1985). Since potassium ions are present in the biological fluids of mammals, the potassium salt of 4-methyl-2-oxovaleric acid, is considered an NHP. Hence, potassium 4-methyl-2-oxovalerate will be considered an NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (isolate) of the Natural Health Product Regulations.
Reference:
Grootegoed JA, Jansen R, Van der Molen HJ. 1985. Intercellular pathway of leucine catabolism in rat spermatogenic epithelium. Biochem. Annexe 1, article 7 (un minéral) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels.";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82648";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"Calcium lactate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195625;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:32:"Transgalactooligosaccharides_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195625";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"96223";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:3502:"The word transgalactooligosaccharides is also spelled trans-galactooligosaccharides and transgalacto-oligosaccharides (Vulevic et al. 2008; Bouhnik et al. 1997). Transgalactooligosaccharides are produced from lactose by enzymatic action of beta-galactosidases that have transgalactosylation activity (Mikkelsen et al. 2004). According to Alles et al. (1999) transgalactooligosaccharide molecules are linear polymers of galactose and lactose with beta-1,6 or beta-1,4 linkages. However, according to Houdijk et al. (2002) transgalactooligosaccharides are beta-linked galactose units. Transgalactooligosaccharides vary in the degree of polymerization (Vulevic et al. 2008). According to van den Heuvel et al. (2002), transgalactooligosaccharides consist of chains of galactose molecules ending usually with a glucose molecule and with the chain length or degree of polymerization from 2 to 8 units. They are considered nondigestible oligosaccharides, since they are largely not affected by human digestive enzymes and reach the colon where they can serve as prebiotics that nourish intestinal microflora (Alles et al. 1999; Vulevic et al. 2008). There is evidence that oral intake of transgalactooligosaccharides can influence intestinal bacteria and have beneficial effects in humans (Silk et al. 2009; Vulevic et al. 2008). During fermentation of milk to produce yogurt, bacteria produce transgalactooligosaccharides from milk sugars (Houdijk et al. 2002). A laboratory analysis found evidence for transgalactooligosaccarides in orange juice, yogurt drink and some other foods (de Slegte 2002).
References:
Alles MS, Hartemink R, Meyboom S, Harryvan JL, Van Laere KM, Nagengast FM, Hautvast JG. 1999. Effect of transgalactooligosaccharides on the composition of the human intestinal microflora and on putative risk markers for colon cancer. Am J Clin Nutr. 69(5):980-91.
Bouhnik Y, Flourié B, D'Agay-Abensour L, Pochart P, Gramet G, Durand M, Rambaud JC. 1997. Administration of transgalacto-oligosaccharides increases fecal bifidobacteria and modifies colonic fermentation metabolism in healthy humans. J Nutr. 127(3):444-448.
de Slegte J. 2002. Determination of trans-Galactooligosaccharides in Selected Food
Products by Ion-Exchange Chromatography: Collaborative Study. Journal of AOAC International 85 (2):417-423.
Houdijk JGM, Verstegen MWA, Bosch MW, van Laere KJM. 2002. Dietary fructooligosaccharides and transgalactooligosaccharides can affect fermentation characteristics in gut contents and portal plasma of growing pigsLivestock Production Science 73: 175-184.
Mikkelsen LL, Knudsen KEB, Jensen BB. 2004. In vitro fermentation of fructo-oligosaccharides and transgalacto-oligosaccharides by adapted and unadapted bacterial populations from the gastrointestinal tract of piglets. Animal Feed Science and Technology
116(Issues 3-4): 225-238.
Silk DB, Davis A, Vulevic J, Tzortzis G, Gibson GR. 2009. Clinical trial: the effects of a trans-galactooligosaccharide prebiotic on faecal microbiota and symptoms in irritable bowel syndrome. Aliment Pharmacol Ther. 29(5):508-518.
van den Heuvel EG, Schoterman MH, Muijs T. 2000. Transgalactooligosaccharides stimulate calcium absorption in postmenopausal women. Journal of Nutrition 130:2938-2942.
Vulevic J, Drakoularakou A, Yaqoob P, Tzortzis G, Gibson GR. 2008, Modulation of the fecal microflora profile and immune function by a novel trans-galactooligosaccharide mixture (B-GOS) in healthy elderly volunteers. Am J Clin Nutr. 88(5):1438-1446.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract ) of the Natural Health Products Regulations";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un extrait) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82649";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:28:"Transgalactooligosaccharides";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"EXT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195626;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:20:"7-methoxyflavone_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195626";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"96232";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:819:"The name 7-methoxyflavone is found in Chemical Book, PubChem and the MeSH of PubMed (NIH). Because of evidence that 7-methoxyflavone can inhibit aromatase, it has been suggested that it might be useful in the prevention or treatment of cancer (Ta and Walle 2007). This compound has been extracted from the plant Conchocarpus heterophyllus, which is in the family Rutaceae (Ambrozin et al. 2004).
References:
Ambrozin ARP, Vieira PC, Fernandes JB, da Silva MFdGF, de Albuquerque S. 2004. Trypanocidal activity of Meliaceae and Rutaceae plant extracts. Mem Inst Oswaldo Cruz. 99(2):227-31.
NIH: National Library of Medicine. MeSH, PubMed. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?db=pubmed
Ta N, Walle T. 2007. Aromatase inhibition by bioavailable methylated flavones.
J Steroid Biochem Mol Biol. 2007 Oct;107(1-2):127-9.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:102:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:107:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 2 (un isolat) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82650";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"7-methoxyflavone";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195627;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:27:"Hydrolyzed beef protein_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195627";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"96228";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1361:"The name “hydrolyzed beef protein” appears in a paper by Lee and colleagues (1998). There is a monograph in the Food Chemicals Codex (FCC 2010) for Acid Hydrolysates of Proteins, which states that they “occur as liquids, pastes, powders, or granules. They are composed primarily of amino acids, small peptides (peptide chains of five or fewer amino acids), and salts resulting from the essentially complete hydrolysis of peptide bonds in edible proteinaceous materials, catalyzed by food-grade acids and/or heat. Cleavage of peptide bonds typically ranges from a low of 85% to essentially 100%.” For the substance :”hydrolyzed beef protein”, enzymes that break peptide bonds could also be used for hydrolysis.
Hydrolyzed beef protein is prepared from material from a non-human animal. Other hydrolyzed protein substances (Protein hydrolysate and Whey protein hydrolysate) have been classified as NHPs (Health Canada 2010). Hydrolyzed beef protein will be considered an NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2 (an extract), of the Natural Health Products Regulations.

Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:5:"Water";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195629;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:27:"L-ornithine-L-aspartate_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195629";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"96524";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:843:"L-ornithine-L-aspartate (LOLA) is a stable salt of L-amino acids: ornithine and aspartic acid1.
Both ornithine and aspartate are endogenic amino acids, which are required by the body for a large number of metabolic processes. L-ornithine is a non-protein, basic amino acid and in the natural way, gets into the urea cycle, which produces urea from ammonia in the liver2.
L-ornithine is used also as a nutritional supplement principally for its putative anabolic activity. Some of the evidence suggests that LOLA restores muscle protein synthesis, an effect which can be exploited in patients suffering from cancer or HIV infections3.

L-Aspartic acid is a non-essential amino acid use for human development.
LOLA will be considered as an NHP, under Schedule 1, Item 4 (amino acid) of the NHP Regulations, since it is a source of 2 amino naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"82734";s:18:"field_parent_space";s:12:"MI Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:26:"Putrescine dihydrochloride";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195706;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:22:"Arsenic trisulfide_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195706";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"99896;93448";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1785:"Arsenic trisulfide (As2S3), also called orpiment or yellow arsenic sulphide, is one of a variety of arsenic sulfide minerals[Merck Index]. It occurs in granular, compact, or powdery form, often in association with the related mineral, red arsenic sulfide (As4S4), or Realgar. These two compounds were used as a pigment in ancient civilizations, and have long history of therapeutic use in traditional medicines. Arsenic trisulfide (As2S3) is mainly used externally as louse-killer, a cure for scabies, snake bites, insect stings, and skin diseases [Chinese Pharmacopeia Committee 2005; Liu et al 2008]. Currently, Arsenic trisulfide (As2S3) has been used to treat MUTZ-1 cells by inhibiting cell proliferation and induce apoptosis, which maybe through activating caspase-3 pathways and increasing the proportion of G2/M phase. Treatment with As2S3 at concentrations of 2, 4, 8 and 16 micromol/L for 48 h resulted in 14.5%, 25.4%, 34.7% and 51.5% inhibition, respectively, and (5.3 +/- 1.8%)%, (11.1 +/- 2.6)%, (19.3 +/- 2.3)% and (25.5 +/- 2.5)% apoptosis rates, respectively[Shao et al. 2009]. Arsenic trisulfide (As2S3) will be considered as NHP, under schedule 1, item 7, Priority 5 (mineral). References:
Merck 2011: The Merck Index Version 14.1. [Online]. Whitehouse Station (NJ): Merck & Co, Inc. [Accessed 2011 October 04]. Available from: http://www.medicinescomplete.com/mc/merck/current/monographs.htm
Shao ZY, Tang M, Chen BA, Xia GH, Zhang L, Zhu HG. 2009. [Experimental study of effect of As2S3 nanoparticles on human MDS cell line (MUTZ-1)]. [Article in Chinese] Zhonghua Xue Ye Xue Za Zhi. 30(1):29-32.
Liu J, Lu Y, Wu Q, Goyer RA, Waalkes MP. 2008. Mineral arsenicals in traditional medicines: Orpiment, realgar, and arsenolite. Chemicals";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:23:"Citric acid monohydrate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"ISO";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:195830;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:8:"Clay_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"195830";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"99187";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1439:"Silicate mineral complex is most commonly known as clay, which is typically a term referring to an aggregate of hydrous silicate particles less than 2 micrometers in diameter. Clay is generally composed of a variety of naturally occurring phyllosilicate minerals (e.g. kaolinite, montmorillonite, pyrophyllite, illite, halloysite), which are rich in silicon and aluminum oxides and hydroxides, including variable amounts of water. These kind of mineral aggregates are generally formed by the chemical weathering of silicate-bearing rocks or by hydrothermal activity, which generally occurs near volcanic activity. Some medicinal roles of phyllosilicates include their use as  antacids, gastrointestinal protectants, antidiarrhoeaics, dermatological protectants and anti-inflammatories [Carretero et al. 2010; Gomes & Silva 2007]. Silicate mineral complex, or Clay, will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 7 (Priority 5; Mineral) of the NHP Regulations. 
Carretero MI, Pozo M. 2010. Review Article: Clay and non-clay minerals in the pharmaceutical and cosmetic industries Part II. Active ingredients. Applied Clay Science 47:171-181.
Gomes CdSF, Silva JBP. 2007. Minerals and clay minerals in medical geology. Applied Clay Science 36:4–21. Lopez-Galindo A, Viseras C, Cerezo P. 2007. Compositional, technical and safety specifications of clays to be used as pharmaceutical and cosmetic products. is a lignan (Lignans, found in plants, are one type of phytoestrogens, which are estrogen-like chemicals and act as antioxidants). Sesamin in (+) form was isolated from Sideritis canariensis, the guggula resin from Commiphora mukul, Xanthoxylum spp., and also pyrethrum flowers (Chrysanthemum cinerariaefolium) and Talauma hodgsoni. It is a constituent of sesame oil and present in the Rutaceae, Piperaceae, Scrophulariaceae, Compositae and Ginkgoaceae. (-)-Sesamin was isolated from the leaves of Magnolia mutabilis and from the bark of Xanthoxylum tingoassuiba, and Acanthopanax sessiliflorus. The racemic form of sesamin is a constituent of Xanthoxylum senegalense and Fagara xanthoxyloides (CRC-DNP 2009). (+)-Sesamin is an insecticide synergist (Merck 2006). Sesamin affects the fatty acid metabolism and lipoprotein production in the liver, and hence lowers the serum lipid levels (Ide, Kushiro et al. 2003). However, Vitamin B6 is a general term for different closely related compounds, namely pyridoxine, pyridoxal and pyridoxamine.  In addition of these 3 acceptable sources of Vitamin B6, different analogs and salts of these derivatives are also considered as acceptable sources of Vitamin B6, such as pyridoxine hydrochloride, pyridoxine 5'-phosphate, pyridoxal hydrochloride, pyridoxal 5'-phosphate, pyridoxamine dihydrochloride and pyridoxamine 5'-phosphate. nicotinate (MN) is an active ingredient in a number of medicinal products as a rubifacient and vasodilator for the treatment of a variety of diseases such as respiratory, vascular and rheumatoid disorders. It has been widely used in cosmetics as an ingredient in skin products like soaps, shampoo and creams due to its rubefacient nature. Aenictus species utilizes MN in its chemical communication system [1]. MN is also an active flavour compound found in fruits like Cupuacu (Theobroma grandiflora) [2-3], Soursop (Annona muricata) [4], Mammee apple (Mammea americana) [5], Strawberries (Fragraria Vesca) [6], Papaya, Guava, headspace of the living orchids Calanthe izu-insularis Ohwi et Satomi (Orcidaceae), Calanthe sieboldii Decne (Orcidaceae) and Tuberose and flowers like calanthe (Orchidaceae) [7]. MN is also reported as an ingredient in rice and rice bran [8]. In the joint meeting of FAO/ WHO experts committee on food additives (JECFA), MN has been accepted as a flavouring agent and there is no safety concern for intake [9]. Methyl nicotinate will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (Isolate).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under monohydrate";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ACN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:3:"MIN";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";}i:196209;a:27:{s:5:"title";s:16:"Hydroquinone_ACN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196209";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2014-02-03";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:12:"93830;109420";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:22:"field_monograph_source";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:961:"Hydroquinone occurs in a variety of forms as a natural product from plants and animals. It has been found in non-volatile extracts of coffee beans and other foods, and as Arbutin (a glucoside of hydroquinone) in the leaves of blueberry, cranberry, cowberry and bearberry plants. Hydroquinones have been isolated from marine sponges of  Dysidea sp. and from the marine colonial tunicate Aplidium californicum. Hydroquinone is also found in the bombardier beetle where it is involved in defensive biochemistry: the beetle can shoot a hot cloud of quinone, formed by the action of hydrogen peroxide, hydroquinone and catalase-peroxidase in the explosion chamber of the beetle, towards an oncoming enemy. The occurrence of hydroquinone in nature can originate from metabolic processes. Hydroquinone can also occur as a metabolite in the biodegradation of substituted phenols. Therefore, hydroquinone will be considered as a NHP that falls under isolate, priority 2.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:131:"This ingredient is pending a When Physostigmine is used ophthalmically as a miotic, the product should be assessed for safety. It is stored primarily in the liver in esterified form (Vitamin A palmitate) and it is a key component of the visual system (when oxidized to retinal) and gene expression (when oxidized to retinoic acid). Retinol/retinyl acetate/retinyl palmitate will be considered as a NHP, acceptable sources of vitamin A will be all-trans retinyl acetate (synthetically prepared from retinol), all-trans retinyl palmitate and all-trans â-carotene. In addition, Vitamin A is also listed in Schedule F as follows:     Vitamin A in oral dosage form containing more than 10,000 International Units of Vitamin A per dosage form or, where the largest recommended daily dosage shown on the label would, if consumed by a person, result in the daily intake by that person of more than 10,000 International Units of Vitamin A. It is stored primarily in the liver in esterified form (Vitamin A palmitate) and it is a key component of the visual system (when oxidized to retinal) and gene expression (when oxidized to retinoic acid). Retinol/retinyl acetate/retinyl palmitate will be considered as a NHP, acceptable sources of vitamin A will be all-trans retinyl acetate (synthetically prepared from retinol), all-trans retinyl palmitate and all-trans â-carotene. In addition, Vitamin A is also listed in Schedule F as follows:     Vitamin A in oral dosage form containing more than 10,000 International Units of Vitamin A per dosage form or, where the largest recommended daily dosage shown on the label would, if consumed by a person, result in the daily intake by that person of more than 10,000 International Units of Vitamin A.  Therefore, Vitamin A over 10,000 IU is considered as drug while below 10,000 is an NHP under Schedule 1, item 3 (Priority 5; Vitamin) of the NHP regulations.    Vitamin A is considered here as the primary proper name, since it is listed in the NHPD Included Natural Health Product Substances (Schedule 1).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:10:"Daily ingredient is pending a decision on its addition to Schedule F of the Food and Drug Regulations which would impact its acceptability as an NHP.  Pancreatin is a substance from the fresh pancreas of the hog or ox, containing the enzymes amylopsin, trypsin and steapsin (digestive enzymes). Each mg of pancreatin contains not less than 25 USP units of amylase activity, not less than 2 USP units of lipase activity, and not less than 25 USP units of protease activity. Pancreatin that is more potent is labeled as a multiple of these three minimum activities, e.g., Pancreatin 4X. ethyl ester is a derivative of amino acid Glutamine. It has been used as as a synthetic substance in several scientific documents- for instance (Lennon 2001; Amato 2005). Glutamine ethyl ester hydrochloride, as the more stable form, is accessible in commercial scale from some suppliers. In supplementation, Glutamine ethyl ester has been used as a source of Glutamine due to its dissociation to the free form in the body by hydrolysis or by esterases (enzymes which cleaves esters). Glutamine ethyl ester will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 2, Priority 2 (source of amino acid Glutamine).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:101:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1, item 2 (an isolate) of the Natural Health Products
